div.head: ff 33â€“3v (3 November)
div.ab:
To the right honourable the Lord
High Tresurer of England.

MyLangley intending to erect a niew stage on the Banckside & against playes. humble duetie remembred to your good Lordship I vnderstand that one ffrancis Langley one of the Alneagers for sealing of cloth intendeth to erect a niew stage or Theater (as they call it) for thexercising of playes vpon the Banck side. And forasmuch as wee fynd by daily experience the great inconvenience that groweth to this Citie & the government thearof by the sayed playes I haue embouldned my self to bee an humble suiter to your good Lordship to bee a means for vs rather to suppresse all such places built for that kynd of exercise then to erect any more of the same sort. I am not ignorant (my very good Lord) what is alleadged by soom for defence of these playes that the people must haue som kynd of recreation & that policie requireth to divert idle heads & other ill disposed from other woorse practize by this kynd of exercize. Whearto may bee answeared (which your good Lordship for your godly wisedom can far best iudge of) that as honest recreation is a thing very meet for all sorts of men so no kynd of exercise beeing of it self corrupt & prophane can well stand with the good policie of a Christian Common Wealth. And that the sayed playes (as they are handled) ar of that sort & woork that effect in such as ar present and frequent the same may soon bee decerned by all that haue any godly vnderstanding & that obserue the fruites & effects of the same conteining nothing ells but vnchast fables, lascivious divises shifts of cozenage & matters of lyke sort. which ar so framed & represented by them that such as resort to see & hear the same beeing of the base & refuse sort of people or such yoong gentlemen as haue small regard of credit or conscience draue the same into example of imitation & not of avoyding the sayed lewd offences. Which may
better appear by the qualitie of such as frequent the sayed pâ€¸layes beeing the ordinary places of meeting for all vagrant persons & maisterles men that hang about the Citie, theeves, horsestealers whoremoongers coozeners connycatching persones practizers of treason & such other lyke whear they consort and make their matches to the great displeasure of Almightie God & the hurt and annoyance of hir Maiesties people both in this Citie & other places about, which cannot bee clensed of this vngodly sort (which by experience wee fynd to bee the very sinck & contagion not only of this Citie but of this whole Realm) so long as these playes & places of resort ar by authoritie permitted. I omit to trouble your Lordship with any farther matter how our apprentices and servants ar by this means corrupted & induced hearby to defraud their Maisters to maintein their vain & prodigall expenses occasioned by such evill and riotous companie whearinto they fall by these kynd of meetings to the great hinderance of the trades & traders inhabiting this Citie, and how people of all sorts ar withdrawen thearby from their resort vnto sermons & other Christian exercise to the great sclaunder of the ghospell & prophanation of the good & godly religion established within this Realm. All which disorders hauing observed & found to bee true I thought it my duetie beeing now called to this publique place to infourm your good Lordship whome I know to bee a patrone of religion a lover of virtue & an honourable a friend to the State of this Citie humbly beeseaching you to voutchsafe mee your help for the stay & suppressing not only of this which is now intended by directing your lettres to the Iustices of peace of Middlesex & Surrey but of all other places if possibly it may bee whear the sayed playes ar shewed & frequented. And thus crauing pardon for this over much length I humbly take my leaue. ffrom London the 3. of November. 1594.

To the right honourable my very good
Lord the Lord High Tresurer of England.

div.p: There is no surviving record of any letter from the privy council to the JPs of Surrey in response to the lord mayor's plea. The manuscript register of the acts of the privy council from 27 August 1593 through 30 September 1595 has been lost; see Dasent (ed), Acts of the Privy Council, vol 24: 1592â€“1593 (London, 1901), vii.
For an abstract of the record and details of its transcription in other sources, see the related EMLoT event record.

div.head: ff 52vâ€“3 (13 September)
div.ab:
OurOur: O in display script humble duty remembred to your good Lordships & the rest: WeeToutching the putting doune of plaies at the Theater & Bankside which â€¸is a great cause of disorder in the Citie: haue been bold heartofore to signify to your Highnesses the great inconvenyenc that groweth to this Cytie by the Common exercise of Stage Plaies, whearin wee presumed to be the more often & earnest suters to your Highnesses ffor the suppressing of the said Stage Plaies aswell in respect of the good government of this Cytie/ which wee desire to be such as her Highnes & your Highnesses might be pleased thearwithall as for conscience sake being perswaded (vnder correccion of your Highnesses Iudgment) that neither in policye nor in religion they ar to be permitted in a Christian Common wealthe specially being of that frame & making as vsually they are, & conteyning nothing but profane fables, Lascivious matters, cozoning devizes, & other vnseemly & scurrilous behaviours, which ar so sett forthe; as that they move wholy to imitacion & not to the avoyding of those vyces which they represent which wee verely think to be the cheef cause aswell of many other disorders & lewd demeanors which appeer of late in young people of all degrees, as of the late stirr & mutinous attempt of those few apprentices and other servantes who wee doubt not driew their infection from these & like places Among other inconvenyences it is not the least that the refuse sort of evill disposed & vngodly people about this Cytie haue oportunitie hearby to assemble together & to make their matches for all their lewd & vngodly practizes: being also the ordinary places for all maisterles men & vagabond persons that haunt the high waies to meet together & to recreate themselfes Whearof wee begin to haue experienc again within these few daies since it pleased her highnes to revoke her Comission graunted forthe to the Provost Marshall, for fear of home they retired themselfes for the time into other partes out of his precinct but ar now returned to
their oldtheir old: also written as catchwords at the foot of f 52v haunt & frequent the Plaies (as their manner is) that ar daily shewed at the Theator & Bankside: Whearof will follow the same inconveniences whearof wee haue had to much experienc heartofore, ffor preventing Whearof wee ar humble suters to your good Lordships & the rest to direct your lettres to the Iustices of peac of Surrey & Middlesex for the present stay & finall suppressing of the said Plaies aswell at the Theator & Bankside as in all other places about the Cytie Whearby wee doubt not but the oportunytie & very cause of so great disorders being taken away wee shalbe able to keepe the people of this Cytie in such good order & due obedienc as that her highness & your Highnesses shalbe well pleased & content thearwithall And so most humbly wee take our LeaueLeaue: final e written over another letter. ffrom London the xiijth of September.1595.1595: underlined

To the right honourable the Lords & others of her
Maiesties most honourable privy Counsell

div.p: The lord mayor probably now had two theatres to worry about on Bankside, both the Rose and Francis Langley's new Swan playhouse in Paris Garden. The mayor had previously expressed anxiety about Langley's intention to erect his playhouse in a letter to Lord Burghley on 3 November 1594.
For an abstract of the record and details of its transcription in other printed sources, see the related EMLoT event record.

div.head: p 317 (22 July)
div.ab: Lettres to the Iustices of Middlesex and Surrey to restrayne the Players from shewing or vsing anie plaies or Interludes in the places vsuall about the Citty of London, for that by drawing of muche people togeather increase of sicknes is feared./

div.p: For an abstract of the record and details of its transcription in others sources, see the EMLoT event record.

div.head: ff 131vâ€“2v
div.ab:
Amphiteatra Londinij sunt IV visendae pulcritudinis quae a diuersis intersignijs diuersa nomina sortiuntur: in ijs varia quotidie scaena populo exhibetur. Horum duo excellentiora vltra Tamisim ad meridiem sita sunt, a suspensis signis ROSA et Cygnus nominata: Alia duo extra vrbem ad septentrionem sunt, viÃ¢ quÃ¢ itur per Episcopalem portam vulgariter Biscopgat nuncupatam. Est et
quintum sed dispari etet: for deletion (?) structura, bestiarum concertationi destinatum, in quo multi vrsi, Tauri, et stupendae magnitudinis canes, discretis caueis & septis aluntur, qui
ad pugnam adseruantur, iucundissimum hominibus spectaculum praebentes, Theatrorum autem omnium prestantissimum est et amplissimum id cuius intersignium est cygnus (vulgo le theater off te cijn) quippe quod tres mille homines in sedilibus admittat, constructum ex coaceruato lapide pyrritide (quorum ingens in Brittannia copia est) ligneis suffultum columnis quae ob illitum marmoreum colorem, nasutissimos quoque fallere posset. Cuius quidem forma quod Romani operis vmbram videatur exprimere supra adpinxi.

div.head: ff 131vâ€“2v
div.ab: There are four amphitheatres in London of evident beauty, which acquire their various names from (their) various signs. In them a different performance is shown daily to the people. The two more exceptional of these, named the Rose and the Swan from (their) hanging signs, are situated south of the Thames. The other two are in the north, outside the city, on the street which is accessed by the bishop's gate, called 'Bishopsgate' in the vernacular. There is also a fifth but of a different structure intended for the fighting of animals, in which many bears, bulls, and dogs of stupendous size are raised in separate cages and enclosures, (and) are reserved for the fight, providing the most delightful spectacle for people. The most outstanding, however, and the largest of all the theatres is the one whose sign is the swan â€“ in the vernacular 'the theatre of the swan' â€“ for it seats 3000 people. It is built from heaped flint stone â€“ of which there is a great abundance in Britain â€“ and is supported by wooden pillars which by their painted marble colour, can deceive the most discerning. Since its form seems to express the shadow of a Roman work, I have made a drawing above.

div.p: The two playhouses outside the city boundaries north of the river were the Theatre and the Curtain. The splendour and generous dimensions of the Swan were later emulated by Philip Henslowe when his second playhouse, the Hope, was built on Bankside in 1613 (see Gilbert Katherens' contract with Henslowe and Jacob Meade for rebuilding the Bear Garden,). A sketch of the Swan's interior based on an original drawing made by the Dutch visitor, Johannes de Witt (1583â€“96), also survives in the recipient's commonplace book, f 132, showing a thrust stage with tiring house and lords' room above in an open yard with three galleries, for which see the manuscript image attached to this record.
For an abstract of the record and details of its transcription in other sources, see the related EMLoT records here, and here.

div.head: ff 85â€“5v (28 July)
div.ab: OurOur: O in display scriptTo the Lords against Stages playes./ humble dutyes remembred to your good Lordships & the rest. Wee haue signifyed to your Highnesses many tymes heartofore the great inconvenience which wee fynd to grow by the Common exercise of Stage Playes. Wee presumed to doo aswell in respect of the dutie wee beare towardes â€¸her highnes for the good gouerment of this her Citie, as for conscience sake, being perswaded (vnder correction of your Highnesses iudgment) that neither in politie nor in religion they are to be suffered in a Christian Common wealth, specially beinge of that frame & matter as vsually they are, conteining nothinge but prophane fables, lascivious matters, cozeinge devises, & scurrilus beehaviour, which are so set forth as that they move wholie to imitation & not totheauoydinge of those faultes & vices which they represent. Amonge other inconveniences it is not the least yat that they give opportunity to the refuze sort of evill disposed & vngodly people that are within and abowte this Cytie to assemble themselves & to make their matches for all theire lewd and vngodly practices; beinge as heartofore wee haue fownd by thexamination of divers apprentices & other seruantes whoe have confessed vnto vs that the saide Staige playes were the very places of theire Randevous appoynted by them to meete with such otheir as wear to ioigne with them in theire designes & mutinus attemptes, beeinge allso the ordinarye places for maisterles men to come together & to recreate themselves. ffor avoydinge wheareof wee are nowe againe most humble & earnest suitours to your honor to dirrect your lettres aswell to our selves as to the Iustices of peace of Surrey & Midlesex for the present staie & fynall suppressinge of the saide Stage playes, aswell at the Theatre Curten and banckside as in all other places in and abowt the Citie, Wheareby wee doubt not but thopportunitie & the very cause of many disorders beinge taken away, wee shalbee more able to keepe the worse sort of such evell & disordred people in better order then heartofore wee haue been. And so most humbly wee take our leaves ffrom London the xxviijth of .Iulie.1597.

TheyThe inconueniencest that grow by Stage playes abowt the
Citie of London./ ar a speaciall cause of corrupting their Youth conteninge nothinge but vnchast matters lascivious devices, shiftes of Coozenage, & other lewd & vngodly practizes, beinge so as that they impresse the very qualitie & corruption of manners which they represent Contrary1 to the rules & art prescribed for the makinge of Comedies eaven amonge the Heathen, who vsed them seldom & at certen sett tymes, and not all the year longe as our manner is. Whearby such as frequent them beinge of the base & refuze sort of people or such young gentlemen as haue small regard of credit or conscience, drawe the same into imitacion and not to the avoydinge the like vices which they represent./

They ar they ordinary places for vagarant persons, Maisterles men, thieves, horse stealers, whoremongers, Coozeners, Conycatchers, contrivers of treason and other2 idole and daungerous persons to meet together & to make theire matches to the great displeasure of Almightie God & the hurt & annoyance of her Maiestes people, which cannot be prevented nor discovered by the Gouernours of the Citie for that they are owt of the Cities iuridiction./

They mayntaine idlenes in such persons as haue no vocation & draw apprentices and3 other seruantes from theire ordinary workes and all sortes of people from the resort vnto sermons and other Christian exercies to the great hinderance of traides & prophanation of religion established by her highnes within this Realm.

In the time of sicknes it is fownd by experience, that many hauinge sores and yet not4 hart sicke take occasion hearby to walk abroad & to recreat themselves by heareinge aplayaplay: for a play. Whearby others ar infected, and them selves also many things miscarry./

div.p: For an abstract of the record and details of its transcription in other printed sources, see the related EMLoT event record.

div.head: p 327 (28 July)
div.ab:
ASigned by the
Lord KeeperLord Keeper: (1540â€“1617), lord keeper of the Great Seal, 1596â€“1617
Lord Treasurer Lord Treasurer: (c 1520â€“98), lord treasurer, 1572â€“98
Lord Admirall Lord Admirall: (c 1536â€“1624), lord admiral, 1585â€“1619
Lord ChamberlenLord Chamberlen: (c 1548â€“1603), second Baron Hunsdon, lord chamberlain of the Household, 1597â€“1603
Lord North Lord North: (1531â€“1600), Lord North
Lord BuckhurstLord Buckhurst: (c 1536â€“1608), first Baron Buckhurst
Mr ComptrollerMr Comptroller: Sir William Knollys (c 1545â€“1632), comptroller of the Household, 1596â€“1632
Mr SecretaryMr Secretary:Sir Robert Cecil (1563â€“1612), secretary of state, 1596â€“1612 Lettre to Robert Wrothe, William ffleetwood, Iohn Barne, Thomas ffowler and Richard Skevington, Esquire and the rest of the Iustices of Middlesex nerest to London. Her Maiestie being informed that there are verie greate disorders Comitted in the Common play houses both by lewd matters that are handled on the Stages and by resorte and Confluence of bad people, hathe giuen direction that not onlie no plaies shalbe vsed within London or about the Citty or in any publique place during this tyme of Sommer, But that also those Play houses that are erected and built only for suche purposes shalbe plucked downe namelie the Curtayne and the Theatre nere to Shorditch or any other within that County. Theis are therfore in her Maiestes name to Chardge and Commaund you that you take present order there be no more plaies vsed in any publique place within three myles of the Citty vntill Alhalloutide next And likewyse that you do send for the owner of the Curtayne, Theatre or anie other Common playhouse, and Inioyne them by virtue hereof forthwith to plucke downe quite the Stages, Gallories and Roomes that are made for people to stand in and so to deface the same as they maie not be ymploied agayne to suche vse, which yf they shall not speedely performe you shall aduertyse vs that order maie be taken to see the same don according to her maiestes pleasure and Commaundment. And hereof praying you not to faile me &c./

The like to Mr. Bowier,Mr. Bowier: Edmund Bowyer(1552â€“1626/7), appointed JP Surrey, 1582 William Gardyner,William Gardyner: William Gardiner(1531â€“97), appointed JP Surrey, 1580, and Bartholomew Scott,Bartholomew Scott: Bartholomew Scott of Camberwell (d. 1600) Esquires and the rest of the Iustices of Surry; Requiring them to take the like order for the Playhouses on the Banckside, in Southwarke, or elswhere in the said County within iij miles of London.

div.p: This order was never carried out and may not have been related to the performance of The Isle of Dogs during the same summer as some have assumed; see Ingram, 'Closing of the Theaters,' pp 105â€“15. Glynne Wickham, while subscribing to the view that the order should be seen in the context of the Isle of Dogs production, has pointed out that the intention of the order was essentially a restraint of public performances in London for three months only, rather than outright suppression of all theatres. In fact, playing resumed at the Curtain and the Rose (but not the Swan) in October and November 1597. As he notes, the Chamberlain's and Admiral's Men were preparing for performances at Court during the Christmas season and both enjoyed the patronage of members of the privy council, so rehearsing for a royal audience would have facilitated their return to those two public stages in the autumn. See further 'The Privy Council Order of 1597 for the Destruction of all London's Theatres,' The Elizabethan Theatre: Papers given at the International Conference on Elizabethan Theatre held at the University of Waterloo, Ontario, in July 1968, David Galloway (ed) (Toronto, 1969), 21â€“44.
For an abstract of the record and details of its transcription in other sources, see the related EMLoT event record.

div.head: Item 23, no 3, single sheet (November) (Bill of Complaint)
div.ab:
To the Quenes moste
Excellent Maiestye

In moste humble and dewtifull manner shewethe and besechethe your highnes your true faithfull and obedyent Subiectes Roberte ShaeRoberte Shae: Robert Shaw (d. 1603), subsequently an actor in Admiral's Men Richard IohnesRichard Iohnes: Richard Jones (d. 1624), subsequently an actor in Admiral's Men until 1602 , Gabrill SpencerGabrill Spencer: Gabriel Spencer (d. 1598) William Birde alias Bourne,William Bird alias Bourne: subsequently an actor in the Admiral's-Prince Henry's-Palsgrave's Men (d. 1624) and Thomas DountoneThomas Dountone: Thomas Downton (d. 1625), subsequently an actor in the Admiral's-Prince Henry's-Palsgrave's Men servantes to the Right honorable the Earle of Pembrooke That wheras your highnes said Subiectes together withe others theire accomplices and associatees haue of longe tyme vsed and professed the Arte of Stageplayinge beinge lawfullye allowed and Aucthorized thervnto duringe whiche tyme your highnes said Subiectes beinge familier and accquainted withe one ffrancis Langlye Citizen and gouldsmithe of London about ffebruary laste in this nyne and thirtye yeare of your highnes most happie and gracious Reigne, fell into Conferrans and Communicacion withe the said Langlie for and aboute the hireinge and takinge a playehowse of the said Langlye scituate in the oulde Parrisgardin in the parishe of St Savyor in the Countye of Surrye Comonlye Called and knowne by the name of the signe of the swanne whiche said speeche and Comunicacion tooke suche effecte (in Respecte of the said Langlie his forwardnes that your said Subiectes should take the same) as they fully Concluded and agreed therefore, and among the diuerse other Agrementes betwene them in and aboute the same the said Langlie Craftelie and Cunninglye intendinge and goinge aboute to Circumvent and ouereache your said Subiectes in and aboute the takinge of the said Howse moved and Required that your said Subiectes woulde become bounde to him the said Langlie in some greate penaltye withe Condicion that they should not absent themselues nor playe els where but in the said plaiehowse Called the swann as aforesaid, whervppon your highness said Subiectes perchance suspectinge the said Langlie his purpose, and dishonest dealinge and Craftie Complott, whihe nowe appearethe verie palpable) for accomplishment that his Requeste in or aboute the Monthe of ffebruary laste in this said Nyne and Thirtithe yeare of your highnes Reignein this â€¦ Reigne: 1596/7 became bounde seuerallye etche by himselfe and for himselfe in ffyve seuerall obligacions in one Hundrithe powndes a pece withe Condicion thervppon indorced amongste other thinges to this or the like effecte that yf your highnes said Subiecte Roberte Shae one of the said Obligors should vntill the Twentithe Daie of ffebruarye nowe nexte Ensuinge in good sorte and manner and from tyme to tyme Continewe and attende as one of the Companie of Players whiche then were agreed to plaie in the said Plaiehowse of him the said Langlie in oulde Parrisgardin aforsaid Called the Swann withoute absentinge himselfe at anie tyme from the Companie when they shoulde so plaie there vnles the said Roberte Shae (your said Subiecte) should in his place and stead bringe in or procure a sufficient persone (suche as the said Langlie or his Assignes should like of) whiche as one of the said Companie should plaie there vntill the said Twentithe Daie of ffebruarie nowe nexte Ensuinge as aforsaid And further yt was Conteined in the said Condicion amongst diuerse other thinges therein Conteined that yf your highnes said Subiecte Roberte Shaa or any other sufficient persone so by him to be appointed and procured should from tyme to tyme vntill the said Twentithe Daie of ffebruarie plaie in the said Playehowse as one of the said Companie and not in anie other place or places within ffyye Miles distant of and from the Citty of London (Excepte pryvate places only) or that the Companie of plaiers should not in the meane tyme plaie within the Citie of London and so allwaies shoulde plaie in the said plaiehowse in manner and forme aforsaid without frawde or Coniuing that then the said obligacion to be voyde, and so Consequentlie etche of your highnes said Subiectes became solie and seuerally bounde by obligacion in the somme of one Hundrithe powndes withe Condicion to the effecte before mencioned But nowe so yt ys moste gracious Souuereigne that sithens that tyme aswell your highnes said Subiectes as all other the Companies of Plaiers in and aboute your highnes said Citye of London haue bin prohibited and Restrained from theire Libertie of playing for some tyme together, And allso the said ffrancis Langlie of a greedy Desire and dishonest disposicion indevoringe and seekinge by all vndewe and indirecte meanes to bringe your said Subiectes into the Danger and forfyture of theire said seuerall obligacons by seaveringe of theire Companie he the said Langlie by means as aforsaid hathe procured from your said Subiectes two of theire Companie so as they Cannott Continewe theire plaie and Exercise as they shoulde nor as the Condicion of the said â€¸seuerall obligacions Requierethe wherby the same are become fforfyted, and nowe the said Langlie havinge thus Lewdly and dishonestlie procured your said Subiectes to incurre the Penaltie of theire said seuerall obligacons and Effected all thinges to his mischevous minde, hathe of late published and gyven oute and still doethe threaten to Comence suite at the Common Lawe against your said Subiectes vppon their said seuerrall obligacons meaninge by the Rigor and stricte Course therof to Recouer the penaltie of ffyve hundrithe powndes of and from your said Subiectes againste all Righte Equitie and good Consciens to their Extreame Ympouerishinge and vtter vndoinge for euer vnles your highnes of your wonted and accustomed Clemencie mercye and grace Releyve them herein In Tender Consideracion wherof and forasmuche as aswell by Reason of the Restraint latly published aswell againste your said Subiectes as all other the Companies of plaiers aforsaid as allso by the Cunninge and Craftie Complottinge of the said ffrancis anglie wilfullie Causinge some of your subiectes said Companie to be sequestred from the reste wherbie they Coulde not Continewe : and performe in playinge as the Wallace Condicion of theire said seuerall bondes Requirethe by meanes wherof the same are become forfyted and : so by the Wallace Course of the Common Lawes your said Subiectes are without all Remedie for theire Releise therein. Maie yt therfore ssessses: please your highnes the premisses Wallace graciously Considered to graunte toyour said Subiectes your most gracious lettres vnder your : previe Seale to be directed to the Wallace said ffrancis Langlie Comandinge him by vertue therof at a Certeine daie and vnder : a Certeine penaltye therin to be lymitted Wallace personally to be and appere bb: before Wallace your highnes Councell in your honorable Courte of Requestes : then and there to answere to the premisses Wallace and to stand to and abide : such order Wallace and direccion therein as to your highnes Councell of the same : Courte shall seeme to stand withe Righte Wallace and Equitie and your said : Subiectes as Wallace they are allready bounde shall dailie praie for the preservacion : bottom of membrane fragmented; of yor Matie in all happines prosperitie and Tranquilitie longe to Reigne and Rule over vs Wallace

div.head: Item 23, no 2, single sheet (24 November) (Answer of Francis Langley)
div.ab:
xxiiijo die Nouembris
Regine Elizabeth Etc xlo/ The Answer of ffrances Langley defendent vnto the bill
of Complaint of Roberte Shawe and others Complainantes./.

The advantage of exception vnto the insufficiencie of the said biil of Complaint to the defendant nowe and all tymes herafter beinge saved the said defendant for answer saieth that the said Shawe and the rest of the Complainantes and theire Complices and Playe fellowes aboute the tyme in the bill menciioned haue been earnest suiters vnto the defendant to have the defendantes howse for to playe in whervpon true yt is that yt was concluded and fully agreed between the nowe defendant and the said Shawe and the reste of the Complainantes with there fellowe players that they should playe in the defendantes said howse for ayere then next and ymmediatly ensweinge and the defendant was to allowe vnto the Complainantes and the rest of ther fellowes players such benefytt as was then likewise agreed between them, And the defendant vppon the said agreement givinge Creditt vnto there faythfull promises disburseddisbursed: b overwritten and layed out for makinge of the said howse ready and providinge of apparell fytt and necessarie for ther playeinge the somme of CCC li. and vpwardes And thervppon true yt is that they became bounden vnto the defendant as in the bill ys alledged But the said Shawe and the rest of the Complainantes not regardinge theire said promise and agreement but Contrariewise beinge resolute and as yt seemeth meaninge to defraude and to deceave the defendent and to make hym to lose most of the Chardges he had disbursed in and aboute the makeinge ready of the said howse & provideinge of the said apparell as aforsaid they the said Complainantes have departed and soe seuered them selfes from the rest of theire Companye without any iust Cawse offered vnto them by the defendant, And soe have euer sithence absented them selfes from the defendantes said howse and soe nowe sithence ther liberty to playe, they have played in the howse of one Philippe Henslowe Comonly Called by the name of the rose on the banckeside, And the defendant for further answer and declaracion of the trueth sayeth that true yt is that their was a restraynte and that aswell the Complainantes as all other the Companyes of players in and aboute the Cyttie of London were prohibited and restrayned from playeinge for atyme as in the bill is supposed but the defendant saieth that the Complainantes were at libertye euer sithence the feast of all Saintes last past (any restrainte to the Contrarie to the defendantes knowledge notwithstandinge) and might have played if yt had pleased them in the defendantes howse as other of ther fellowes have done but the Complainantes have euer sithence refused to playe in the defendantes howse and ther by haue wilfully forfeited their said bondes. And therfore the defendant hopeth that in lawe equitie and conscience he maye lawfully sue and ympleade them the said Complainantes vpon their said bondes for and in respect of the great Costes and Chardges he hath disbursed and layed owt at and by ther appoyntment and direction for the makeinge ready of the playe howse and furnishinge hym self with sundry sorte of Riche attire and apparell for them to playe withall wherof the defendant hath euer sithence had lytle vse beinge bought and provided for them to playe withall as aforesaid/ without that/ that the defendant ether Craftely or Conyinge intendinge or goeinge aboute to circumvente or ouermache the Complainantes in or aboute the takeinge of the said howse moved or required that the Complainantes or any of them would become bounden to the defendante otherwise then before in this the defendantes answer is truely sett furth and declared, or that, that the defendant of agreedy desire or dishonest disposicion indevored or sought by any indirect or vndue meanes to bringe the Complainantes into the danger of forfeiture of ther said seuerall obligacions, by seueringe of ther Companye or that, that the defendant hath procured from the Complainantes two of their Companyons soe as they Could not Contynewe ther playe and excercise as they shold or as they were bounde in and by theire said seuerall obligacions as the Complainantes in their said bill of Complaint have most vntruely surmised And without, that, that the defendant hath lewdly or dishonestly procured the Complainantes to incurre the penaltie of theire said seuerall obligacions vppon any mischieveous mynde or hath of late published or geven out or still doth threten to comence suite at the Common lawe against the Complainantes vpon the said seuerall obligacions otherwise then lawfull is for hym to doe inasmuch as they the said Complainantes have wilfully rune into the danger of the forfeyture of the said bondes in withdrawinge and absenting them selfes from the defendentes howse and contynuinge of there playes in other howses./ the defendante as aforesaid haveinge disbursed and layed out in provision of apparell and makeinge of all thinges ready as aforesaid the full somme of CCC li. as aforesaid/ And without that, that any other matter or thinge matteriall mencioned in the said bill of Complaint, And not before by this defendant in his answer sufficiently Answered vnto Confessed & avoyded deyned or trauersed is true All which matters this defendant is ready to averre & prove as this honorable Corte shall awarde and prayeth to be dismissed with his reasonable Costes & Chardges for his wrongfull vexacion herin susteyned./.

div.p: The prohibition of plays referred to was issued by the privy council on 28 July 1597; see Sally-Beth MacLean (ed), Rose Playhouse, REED (Toronto, 2023).
For an abstract of the record (Item 23, no 3) and details of the transcription in other sources, see the related EMLoT event record.

div.head: p 346 (15 August)
div.ab: A Lettre to Richard Topclyfe, Thomas ffowler, and Richard Skevington esquirs, doctour ffletcher and mr Wilbraham. vppon Informacion given vs of a lewd plaie that was plaied in one of the plaie howses on the Bancke side contanynge very selatious & sclandrous matter, wee caused some of the Players to be apprehended & comytted to pryson, whereof one of them was not only an Actor, but a maker of parte of the said Plaie; ffor as moche as yt ys thought meete that the rest of the Players or actors in that matter shalbe apprehended to receave soche punyshment as theire leude and mutynous behavior doth deserve; These shalbe therefore to Requir yow to examine those of the plaiers that are comytted whose names are knowne to yow Mr Topclyfe, what ys becom of the rest of theire ffellowes that either had there partes in the devysinge of that sedytious matter, or that were Actors or plaiers in the same, what Copies they haue given forth of the said playe, and to whome, and soch other pointes as yow shall thincke meete to be demaunded of them, wherein yow shall requir them to deale trulie as they will looke to receave anie favor. Wee praie yow also to pervse soch papers as were fownde in Nash his Lodginges, which fferrys a messenger of the Chamber shall delyver vnto yow, And to Certyfie vs thexamynacions yow take So &c./

div.p: Richard Topcliffe (1531â€“1604) was employed by the government to interrogate suspects and was known as a cruel torturer; see William Richardson, 'Topcliffe, Richard (1531â€“1604), interrogator and torturer,' ODNB, accessed 30 October 2024. Thomas Fowler and Richard Skevington are named with other JPs of Middlesex in the 28 July 1597 privy council order attempting to suppress playhouses in the London area; see. 'doctour ffletcher' was Giles Fletcher (1546â€“1611), appointed remembrancer of the city of London in 1586; see further Lucy Munro, 'Fletcher, Giles, the elder (bap. 1546, d. 1611), diplomat and author,' ODNB, accessed 30 October 2024. Mr Wilbraham was likely Richard Wilbraham (d. 1601), common serjeant of the city of London.

Nash, the playwright, beat a hasty retreat to Great Yarmouth where he remained for some months, not without loss of income and reputation. His 1599 pamphlet, Nashes Lenten Stuffe, reflects on the experience: 'THe straunge turning of the Ile of Dogs from a commedie to a tragedie two summers past, with the troublesome stir which hapned aboute it, is a generall rumour that hath filled all England, and such a heavie crosse laide vpon me, as had well neere confounded mee: I meane, not so much in that it sequestred me from the woonted meanes of my maintenance, which is as great a maime to any mans happinesse, as can bee feared from the hands of miserie, or the deepe pit of dispaire wherinto I was falne, beyond my greatest friendes reach to recouer mee: but that, in my exile and irkesome discontented abandonment, the silliest millers thombe, or contemptible stickle-banck of my enemies, is as busie nibbling about my fame, as if I were a deade man throwne amongest them to feede vpon. That infortunate imperfit Embrion of my idle houres the Ile of Dogs before mencioned, breeding vnto me such bitter throwes in the teaming as it did, and the tempestes that arose at his birth, so astonishing outrageous and violent as if my braine had bene conceiued of another Hercules, I was so terrifyed with my owne encrease (like a woman long trauailing to bee deliuered of a monster) that it was no sooner borne but I was glad to run from it. Too inconsiderate headlong rashnesse this may be censured in me, in beeing thus prodigall in advantaging my aduersaries, but my case is no smoothered secret, and with light cost of rough cast rethorieke it may be tollerablely playstered ouer, if vnder the pardon and priuiledge of incensed higher powers it were lawfully indulgenst me freely to aduocate my owne astrology. Sufficeth what they in their graue wisdoomes shall proscribe, I in no sorte will seeke to acquite, nor presumptuously attempte to dispute against the equity of their iudgementes, but, humble and prostrate appeale to their mercies. Avoide or giue grounde I did, scriptum est, I will not goe from it, and post varios casus, variable Knight arrant aduentures, and outroades, and inroades, at greate Yarmouth in Norfolke I ariued in the latter ende of Autumne' (STC: 18370, sigs Bâ€“Bv).

The privy councillors listed as present at the meeting (p 345) were Sir William Cecil (1520/1â€“98), lord treasurer, 1572â€“98; George Carey (1548â€“1603), second Baron Hunsdon, chamberlain of the Household, 1597â€“1603; Roger North (1531â€“1600), Lord North; Sir William Knollys (c 1545â€“1632), comptroller of the Household, 1596â€“1632; Sir Robert Cecil (1563â€“1612), secretary of state, 1596â€“1612; and Sir John Fortescue (c 1533â€“1607), chancellor of the Exchequer, 1589â€“1603.

div.head: f [1] (10 August)
div.ab: Right honorable this gentilman the bearer herof, To whome I did wryte yester night, did this morninge Cume speedely vnto me, And when he did perceaue that your pleasor was that he should wayt vpon yow He did tacke comfort, & harty hoape, That it was for his good And that throwghe my humble suwte, It hathe pleased yow to renewe your good conceate of hym I did speak as I thought to hym, and do wryte this to yow, as in my Sowle I am resolved withovt Arte// And I haue lifted vpp his hart agein with lettinge hym knowe That her maaiesty is so well pleassed with hym, & your honour also, for the prooffe he laytly mayd to me of his loyall harte, To bee ye first man That discoverred to me that sedycioos play Cawlled The Ile of doggsCawlled â€¦ doggs: in italic script// in his opynyon as a venomooss intent & a preparatyve to sume farrefetched mischieffe & I cannot over often saye was good prooffe of his Loyaltee/

div.p: For an abstract of the record and details of its transcription in other sources, see the related EMLoT event record.

div.head: p 181 (19 February) (Whitehall)
div.ab: AA: in display script lettre to the Master of the RevellesMaster of the Revelles: Edmund Tilney, master of the Revels, 1579â€“1610 and Iustices of Peace and of Middlesex & Surrey. Whereas licence hath bin graunted vnto two Companies of Stage Players retayned vnto vs the Lord AdmyralLord Admyral: Charles Howard, tenth earl of Nottingham and lord admiral 1585â€“1619 and Lord Chamberlain Lord Chamberlain: George Carey, second Baron Hunsdon and lord chamberlain of the Household, 1597â€“1603, to vse and practise Stage Playes, whereby they might be the better enhabled and prepared to shew such plaies before her Maiestie as they shalbe required at tymes meete and accustomed, to which ende they haue bin Cheefelie licensed and tollerated as aforesaid: And whereas there is also a third Company who of late (as wee are informed) haue by waie of intrusion vsed likewise to play, having neither prepared any plaie for her Maiestie, nor are bound to yow, the Masters of the Revelles, for perfourming such orders as haue bin prescribed, and are enioyned to be obserued by the other two Companies before mencioned; Wee haue therefore thought good to require yow, vpon receipt heereof to take order that the aforesaid third Company may be suppressed, and none suffered heere after to plaie; but those two formerlie named belonging to vs the Lord Admyrall and Lord Chamberlaine, vnles yow shall receaue other direccion from vs. And so &c./

div.p: The third company that had drawn the ire of the privy council is not identified here but this letter provides evidence that attempts to limit the number of companies and playhouses in the London area continued to be unsuccessful. The Lord Admiral's Men remained based at the Rose until 1600 when the Fortune playhouse opened in Clerkenwell north of the city wall.
For an abstract of the record and details of its transcription in other printed sources, see the related EMLoT event record.

div.head: p 323 (20 April)
div.ab: ItemItem: in display script it is Ordered that a viewe shalbe made by the Churchwardens howe manye newe tenementes mr Langlye hath builded since the Order sett downe for his Tythes And that they shall speake to mr Langlye & mr Henslowe & Iacob Meade for monie for the pore, in Regarde of theire plaies/

div.head: p 324 (1 May)
div.ab: ItemItem: in display script it is ordered that mr Langlyes newe buildinges shalbe vyewed accordinge to an order the last Vestrey And that he, mr Henslowe & Iacob Meade shalbe mooved for monie for the pore in regarde of theire playehouses/

div.head: p 325 (19 July)
div.ab: InprimisInprimis: in display script it was ordered at this vestrye that a peticion shalbe made to the bodye of the Councell concerninge the playehouses in this paryshe wherein the enormyties shalbe shewed that comes therebye to the paryshe And that in respecte thereof they maye be dismissed & putt downe from playeinge and that iiij or ij of the Churchwardens, mr Howse,mr Howse: Thomas Howse, auditor, 1598 mr Garlonde,mr Garlonde: Thomas Garlonde (?), churchwarden, 1597 mr Iohn Payne,mr Iohn Payne: auditor, 1597 mr Humble,mr Humble: auditor, 1597 or ij of them & mr Russellmr Russell: Oliver Russell (?), churchwarden, 1598 & mr Ironmongermr Ironmonger: Thomas Ironmonger, surveyor of church lands, 1598 or one of them shall presente the cause with a Collector of the Borowghside & an other of the Bankside/

div.p: For an abstract of the record (p 323) and details of its transcription in other sources, see the related EMLoT event record.

In 1589 Francis Langley had acquired the lordship of the manor of Paris Garden, west of Bankside in the parish of St Saviour, Southwark. By 1595 he had opened a second playhouse there, the Swan, which must have increased the traffic of playgoers across the Thames to the area (for further details and illustrations, see the Introduction). Jacob Meade (1557-1624) was a waterman, resident in the Clink liberty and Henslowe's partner in the later Hope/Bear Garden enterprise. It seems possible from this entry in the vestry minutes that he may have had an association with Henslowe for the Rose as well as the Bear Garden by 1598, around the time when he was appointed keeper of the Royal Game of Bears, Bulls, and Mastiff Dogs (see further Warner, Catalogue, p 234). Meade first appears in 1597 as a resident of Rose Alley in the Clink in the St Saviour Token Books. The playhouses concerned here and below are Langley's Swan in Paris Garden manor and Henslowe's Rose in the Clink liberty, both within the parish boundaries of St Saviour's.
For an abstract of the record (p 325) and details of its transcription in other sources, see the related EMLoT event record.

div.head: Item 23, no 1, single sheet (6 February 1597/8) (Replication of Robert Shawe et al)
div.ab:
Thevjo die ffebruarij Anno Regine
Elizabethae &c xlmo Replicacyon of Robart Shawe Richard Iones Gabriell Spencer
William Byrd alias Bourne and Thomas Dounton Complainantes to the
Answeare of ffrauncys Langley Defendent/

TheThe: large T said Complainantes and euery of them doe averr and maintaine their said Bill of Complaint and all and euery the matters therein conteyned to be true certeine and sufficient in the Lawe to be A A: Answeared Wallace vnto in such sort as in the same they are trulie sett furth and declared And saye that the Answears of the said defendent ys very vntrue incerteine and insufficient in the Lawe to be replyed vnto for diuers imperfeccions therein very manifestly appearinge The benefytt of excepcions to the incertentie and insufficiencye whereof being to the said Complainantes and euery of them nowe and at all : tymes Wallace hereafter saved and allowed/ And by protestacion not confessing or acknowledging any materyall thing or matter in the said Answeare conteyned concerning the said Complainantes or any : of them Wallace to be true other then that which hereafter shalbe confessed for Replicacion to the said Answar of the said defendent they saye and euery of them sayeth in all thinges as in their said Bill : of Complaint Wallace they have sayed And further Replye and saye that the said defendant vppon agreament betwene him and three of the Companye of the said Complainantes did deliuer vnto them there said obligac obligac: obligacions whereby Wallace they weare imboldened to depart from the societie of theise Complainantes, soe that theise Complainantes cold not according to the Condicion of the said obligacion, contynue in the same societye and companye : of them Wallace in the said howse of the said defendent And as touching the departure and absence of theise Complainantes from the howse of the said defendent The cause thereof was well knowen aswell to the said defendent : as Wallace to others for that by her Maiesties authoritye and comaundementes a restraint was publikly made aswell of the said Complainantes as all other Companies of players in and about her Maiesties Citye of London from playing in any of the said play howses in or neare the said Citie. And the owners of the same howses likewyse prohibited to suffer any playes in the same seuerall howses from about the feast daye of Saint Iames the Appostle vntill aboute the feast of All Saintes Last past, Wherevppon (after that theise Complainantes had obtayned lycence to playe againe) they resorted to the said defendent and offered them selves to playe in the howse of the said defendent according to the Condicion of their obligacion as formerly they had done (yf the said defendent would bear them out) whoe Answeared that he would not bear the Compainantes out But sayd he had lett to them his howse and bade them doe what they would, The Complainantes then Replyed and sayd that they durst not play in his howse without lycence, And that yt was to their vndoeing to Contynue in Idleness And that Phillippe Henslow (in the said Answear named) had obtayned lycens for his howse and would beare the Complainante s out (yf they would goe to him, Then the said defendent sayd that the Complainantes weer left to goe to him which the Complainantes Conceaved and tok for a Lycens of the said defendent And that he ment well to the Complainantes that they should healpe them selves to gett their lyving, synce which tyme theise Complainantes have exercysed their playinge at the howse of the said Phillipp Henslowe (as lawfully they might) And theise Complainantes are nowe perswaded that the said defendent vsed the said wordes videlicet (that then the said Complainantes might goe play in the howse of the said Phillippe Henslowe, of pollicye to drawe them into the penaltie and daunger of the forfayture of their obligacions and not for any other purpose without that thatthat that: dittography the said Complainantes and their Complices and playfellowes weare earnest sutours vnto the defendent to have the defendentes howse to play In, in such manner and form as in the said Answear of the defendent verie vntrulie ys alledged, for the said Complainantes saye that the said defendent desyred them the Complainantes to playe in his said howse And therevppon the said agreament was made as in the said Bill of Complaint ys allso trulie declared, And without that that the said defendent geving Creddytt vnto the faithfull promises of the Complainantes, disbursed and Layd out for making of the said howse and provyding for apparell fytt and necessary for their playing, the somme of Three hundred poundes and vpwardes in such manner and forme as in the said Answear verie vntrulie ys allso alledged, for the said Complainantes for further Replicacion say that for the making of the said howse redye and fytt for the Complainantes to play In The said defendent was at noe cost at all, for the said howse was then lately afore vsed to have playes in hit, And yf the said defendent werre at charges for the provyding of apparell the said Complainantes saye, the same was vppon his owne offer and promise that he by the same agreament was to provyde the same, And afterwardes to acquaint the Complainantes with value thereof, And that the defendent should be allowed for the true value thereof out of the Complainantes moytie of the gains for the seuerall standinges in the galleries of the said howse which belonged to them which the said Complainantes have faithfullye performed from tyme to tyme, And the said Complainantes further say that the said howse of the defendent might have longe contynewed without gaines (yf they the said Complainantes had not vppon request of the defendent exercysed their playing therein, Whereby the defendent hath gayned at lest a hundred powndes and more by theise Complainantes And hath allso receaved for apparell which he in his Answeare alledgeth to be provyded for the Complainantes a hundred powndes & above out of : the said Wallace moytie which was due to the Complainantes as aforesaid, And hath all the said apparell to him self part whereof the Complainantes have trulie paid for & therefore ought to have the same again of the said defendent or Consideracion for the same And without that that the said Shawe and the other Complainantes did not regard their promise and agreament or did contrarywyse resolve with any meaning to defraude and deceave the defendent and to make him lose most or any the charges he had disbursed in and aboute the making redy of the said howse, and provyding of the sayd apparell in such manner and forme as in the said Answeare of the said defendent verie vntrulie ys allso alledged/ for theise Complainantes desyred to the Bill of accompt of the defendent and he should have such money he had disbursed according to the agreament betwene theise Complainantes and him which he refused and tok the apparell and Converted the same to his best profytt by lending the same for hyre whereby he hath receaved great gaynes, Or that the said Complainantes have departed and severed themselues from the rest of their Company without any iust cause vnto them by the defendent geven in such manner and form as in the said Answear vntruly ys alledged, And without that that the said defendent hath sustayned any losse by reason of theise Complainantes, for he the said defendent hath euer synce had his said howse contynually from tyrne to tyme exercysed with other players to his great gaines. And without that that the Complainantes have euer synce refused to playe in the defendentes howse and thereby have willfully forfyted their bondes in such manner and form as in the said Answear very vntruly ys alledged, for the said Complainantes say (as befor they have truly declared) that the cause, was for that the said defendent did advyse them to goe to the said Henslowes howse as aforesaid, And allso for that the defendent had in such subtill sort procured some of their Companies to be separated from them as aforesaid, And without that that the defendent in Lawe equity or Consciens may Lawfully sue and impleade them the Complainantes vppon their said bondes for & in respect of the supposed great costes and chardges he hath disbursed and laid out by their appointment and dyreccion eyther for the supposed making readye of the said play howse or furnishing himself with sondrye sort of Rich Attyre and apparell for them to play withall in such manner and forme as in the said Answear very vntruly ys alledged, Or that the Defendent hath euer sythence had litle vse of the same apparell being bought and provyded for them to play withall in such manner and forme as in the said Answear very : vntruly ys Wallace allso alledged for the said Complainantes for further Replicacion say that the said defendent doth vsually from tyme to tyme lett out the said apparell to his great advauntage : & gain whereof Wallace the Complainantes ought to have part for that they truly paid for part of the same apparell which the said defendent maketh noe litle gaines of, And therefore the said Complainantes humblie praie this honourable Cort to tak some order wherby the defendent may be Compelled to deliuer such of the same apparell soe payd for by the Complainantes to them the said Complainantes or recouer for the same and to have their said obligacion deliuered vnto them, which that that the said Complainantes doe and will averre and prove that the said defendent of a greadye : Desyre and Wallace dishonest disposicion did endevour and sought by indyrect and vndewe meanes to bring the Complainantes into the daunger of forfyture of their said seuerall obligacions by severyng of their Companies as before ys truly declared, And with that allso that the sayd defendent hath procured from the Complainantes three of their Companions so as they cold not contynue their play and exercyse as they should or as they were bound in & by their said seuerall obligacions, in such sort as the said Bill of Complaint ys alledged without that that the said Complainantes have willfully runne into the forfeyture of their bondes in withdrawing and absenting them selves from the defendentes said howse : ys true Wallace (by the Coning pollicy and practise of the defendent by drawing entycing or procuring some of their Companions from them whereby they cold not play) The said defendent : hopeth and Wallace meaneth thereby to have the penaltie of the said bondes as befor ys trulye declared. And without that that the defendent hath disbursed or Layd out in provision of : and for the Wallace making of all thinges redy the full some of three hundred poundes in such manner and form as in the said Answeare very vntruly ys alledged And without that that : any other Wallace thing or matter in the said Answear conteyned concerning these Complainantes or any of them materiall or effectuall to be Replyed vnto, And in this Replicacion not : confessed Wallace avoyded trauersed denyed or otherwyse sufficiently Replyed vnto, ys true, AII which matters the said Complainantes are redy to averr and prove as this honourable Court shall award, And pray (as before in their said Bill of Complaint) they have prayed./prayed: Wallace notes that the solicitor's signature is illegible at the end

div.p: For an abstract of the record and details of its transcription in other sources, see the related EMLoT event record.

div.head: ff 285vâ€“6
div.ab:
As Antipater Sidonius was famous for extemporall verse in Greeke, and Ouid for his Quicquid conabar dicere versus erat:Quicquid â€¦ erat: 'Whatever I tried to write was verse.' Cp. Ovid, Tristia, IV.X.26 so was our TarletonTarleton: Richard Tarleton (d.1588), famous clown and member of the Queen's Men of whome Doctour Case that learned physitian thus speaketh in the seuenth Booke, & seuenteenth chap
ter of his Politikes; Aristoteles suum TheodoretumTheodoretum: for Theodorum laudauit quendam peritum Tragoediarum actorem; Cicero suum Roscium: nos Angli Tarletonum, in cuius voce & vultu omnes iocosi affectus, in cuius cerebroso capite lepidae facetiae habitant.Aristoteles â€¦ habitant: 'Aristotle praised his Theodorus, a certain skilled actor of tragedies; Cicero, his Roscius; we English, Tarleton, in whose voice and face all sportive emotions, in whose mad head witty jests dwell.' And so is now our wittie Wilson,Wilson: Robert Wilson, actor and playwright, member of Leicester's and then the Queen's Men who, for learning and extemporall witte in this facultie, is without compare or compeere, as to his great and eternall commendations he manifested in his chalenge at the Swanne on the Banke side.

div.p: The quote (slightly inaccurate here) can be found in the second edition of John Case's commentary on Aristotle's Politics, Sphaera Civitatis (Oxford, 1588), 691; STC: 4761.

div.head: p 405 (29 May)
div.ab: Eodem die./

In the matter in varyaunce depending before the Queenes maiestie & her highenes CounsaillShawe
Langley of her honourable Court of Whitehall at the sute of Robert ShaweRobert Shawe: Robert Shaw (d. 1603), subsequently an actor in Admiral's Men
Richard Iohnes,Richard Iohnes: Richard Jones (c 1560â€“1624), subsequently an actor in Admiral's Men until 1602 Gabriell Spencer,Gabriell Spencer: Gabriel Spencer (1576â€“98) William Birde alias BourneWilliam Birde â€¦ Bourne: William Bird alias Bourne: subsequently an actor in the Admiral's-Prince Henry's-Palsgrave's company (d. 1624) & Thomas DowntonThomas Downton: Thomas Downton (d. 1625), subsequently an actor in the Admiral's-Prince Henry's-Palsgrave's company complainantes, against ffrauncis Langley defendant. Being for & concerninge the stay of the defendant his proceedinges at the common lawe against the sayde complainantes vppon five seuerall obligacions of one hundred poundes A peece wherein the saide complainantes stande seuerally bounden to the said defendant with condicion for the performance of certen covenauntes & agreementes made betweene the sayd complainantes & defendant vppon conference & communicacion had betwixt them for & about the hyring & taking of A playhowse of the said defendant scituate in the olde Parisgarden in the parishe of St Saviour in the county of Surrey, As in and by the said Complainant in theire saide bill of complaint is more at lardge sett furth & declared. It is this present day by her Maiestes sayde Counsaill of this Court in presence of Counsaill on both sydes, Ordered that the said defendant his Counsailour. Attournees sollicitoures & ffactours & euery of them shall from henceforth surcease & stay & no further prosecute or proceede at the common lawe vppon the sayd obligacions or any of them against the sayd complainant vntill it shall please her maiestes sayd Counsaill to take further order for the finall ending & determining of this cause And it is further by her maiestes sayd Counsaill Ordered that an Iniunccion vnder her maiestes Privie Seale vppon paine of vC li. shalbe awarded furth of this Court & directed to the said defendant his Counsailours Attournees sollicitours & factours & euery of them for the due performance of this present order/

div.p: For an abstract of the record and details of its transcription in other sources, see the related EMLoT event record.

div.head: p 230 (22 June) (Greenwich)
div.ab:
Lettres22. Iune. of this tenour to the Lord Maiour of London, the Iustices of the peace of theLord Keeper. Lord Keeper: Sir John Puckering (c 1543â€“96), lord keeper of the Great Seal, 1592â€“6Lord North.Lord North: Roger North (1531â€“1600), second Baron North
Lord TreasurerLord Treasurer: (c 1520â€“98), lord treasurer, 1572â€“98Master Secretary.Master Secretary: (1532â€“90), principal secretary, 1573â€“90
Lord Admyrall. Lord Admyrall: (c 1536â€“1624), lord admiral, 1585â€“1619Mr Comptroller. Mr Comptroller: William Knollys, first earl of Banbury (c 1545â€“1632), lord comptroller, 1596â€“1602
Sir Iohn ffortescu:Sir Iohn ffortescu: (1533â€“1607) Counties of Midlesex and Surrey. By occasion of some Complaintes that of late haue bin made vnto vs of the multitude of houses seruinge for Common stage playes in and aboute the Citty of London, and of the greate abuses and disorders growen by the ouermuch haunte and resorte of many licentious people vnto those houses and places, we haue entred into Consideracion of some fitt course to be taken for redresse of thesaide disorders by suppressing dyuers of those houses and by some restrainte of the imoderate vse of the plaies. ffor which cause wee haue sett downe certaine orders to be duely henceforth obserued, and kept, a Copy whereof we sende yow hereinclosed and haue sent the like to the Lord Maiour of London. and to the Iustices of the peace of Middlesex. But as wee haue done our partes in prescribinge the orders so vnlesse yow perfourme yours in lookinge to the due execution of them. we shall loose our labour, and the wante of redresse must be imputed vnto yow, and others vnto whome it apperteyneth. And therefore wee doe hereby authorize and require yow to see the saide orders to be putt in execucion, and to be Continued as yow do wish the Amendement of the aforesaide abuses; and will remoue the blame thereof from yourselues./. And so &c.

div.p: The list of names in the left marginalia accounts for those in attendance at the privy council meeting on 22 June 1600.
For an abstract of the record and details of its transcription in other sources, see the related EMLoT event record.

div.head: pp 223â€“4 (22 June) (Greenwich)
div.ab:
OrderAt the Courte at Greenwich. of the Lords for the restrainte of the imoderate vse and Companye
of Playhowses and Players.

WhereasWhereas: W in display script.22. of Iune diuers Complaintes haue bin heretofore made vnto the Lordes & others of her Maiesties priuye Counsell, of the manyfolde abuses and disorders that haue growen and do contynue by occasion of many houses erected and employed in and about the Cittie â€¸of London for Common stage playes And now verie latelie by reason of some Complainte exhibited by sondry persons againste the buyldinge of the like housethe like house: Fortune playhouse in or near â€¸Golding Lane bouglane, by one Edward Allen a Servant of the right honorable the Lord AdmyrallLord Admyrall: Charles Howard (c 1536â€“1624), tenth earl of Nottingham and lord admiral, 1585â€“1619 the matter aswell in generaltie touchinge all the saide houses for stage playes and the vse of playinge as in particular concerninge the saide house now in hand to be buylte in or neare â€¸Golding bougl Lane, hath bin broughte into question and consultacion amonge their Lordships. fforasmuch as it is manifestley knowen and graunted that the multitude of the saide houses, and the mysgouerment of them hath bin and is dayly occasion, of the ydle ryoutous, and dissolute living of great Nombers of people, that leavinge all such honest and painefull course of life as they should followe, doe meete and assemble there and of many particular abuses and disorders that doe therevpon ensue; And yet Neuertheles it is considered that the vse and excercise of suche playes (not beinge euill in yt self) may with a good order and moderacion be suffered in a well gouerned state; and that her Maiestie beinge pleased at some tymes to take delight and recreation in the sight and hearinge of them, some order is fitt to be taken for the allowance and maynetenaunce of such persons as are thought meetest in that kinde to yealde her Maiestie recreation and delighte, and consequently of the houses that must serue for publike playinge to keepe them in exercise; To the ende therefore that both the greatest abuses of the playes and playinge houses may be redressed, and yet the aforesaide vse and moderation of them retayned, The Lordes and the reste of her Maiestes privie Counsell, with one and full consent haue ordered in manner and forme as followeth.

ffirste that there shalbe aboute the Cittie two houses and no more, allowed to serue for the vse of the Common stage playes; of the which houses one shalbe in Surrey, in that place which is Commonly called the Banckeside or thereaboutes and the other in Middlesex.Middlesex: followed by a blank space approximately 7 characters in length And forasmuch as their Lordships haue bin enformed by Edmund Tylney esquier her Maiestes Servante and Master of the Revelles that the house nowe in hand to be builte by thesaide Edward Allen is not intended to encrease the Nomber of the play houses but to be insteede of an otherMemorandum, that the alteracion and interlying of this order was by reason that the said order after the same was entred in the Booke came againe in question and debate, and the said interlyninge & amendementes were sett downe according to the laste determinacion of their lordshipes. ThomasSmithThomasSmith: clerk of the council (namely the Curtayne) which is ether to be ruyned and plucked downe or to be put to some other good vse as also that the scytuation thereof is meete and convenient for that purpose; it is like wise ordered that the saide house of Allen shalbe allowed to be one of the two houses, and namely for the house to be allowed in Middlesex â€¸for the Company of players belonging to the Lord Admyrall so as the house called the Curtaine be (as it â€¸is hath bin) pretended) either ruynated or applyed to some other good vse And for the other house allowed to be on Surrey side whereas â€¸their lordships are pleased to permitt : cancelled text approximately 45 characters in length to the Company of players that shall play there to make their owne Choice which they will haue â€¸of diuers houses that are there choosing one of them and no more

â€¸And ye said company of plaiers beinge the Servantes of the lord Chamberlain that are to play there haue made choise of the house called the Globe, it is ordered that the said house and none other shalbe there allowed. And especially it is forbidden that any stage playes shalbe played (as some tymes they haue bin) in any Common Inne for publique assembly in or neare about the Cittie./

Secondly, forasmuch as these stage plaies, by the multitude of houses and company of players haue bin so frequent not servinge for recreation but invitinge and callinge the people dayly from their trade and worke to misspend their tyme
it is likewise ordered that the two seuerall Companies of players assigned vnto the two houses allowed may play each of them in their seuerall houses twice a weeke and no oftener, and especially that they shall refrayne to play on the Sabbath Day vpon paine of imprysonment and further penaltie: and that they shall forbeare altogether in the tyme of Lent and likewise at such tyme & tymes as any extraordinary sicknes or infection of disease shall appeare to be in or about the Cittie./

Thirdly because the orders wilbe of little force and effecte vnlesse they be duely putt in execution, by those vnto whome it appertayneth to see them executed; It is ordered that seuerall Copies of these orders shalbe sent to the Lord Maior of London; and to the Iustices of the peace of the Counties of Middlesex and Surrey. and that lettres shalbe written vnto them from their Lordships, straightly charginge them to see to the execucion of the same, aswell by Comyttinge to prison any owners of play houses and players as shall disobey and resist these orders, as by any other good and lawfull meanes that in their discretion they shall finde expedient, and to certifie their Lordships from tyme to tyme, as they shall see cause of their proceedinges herein.

div.p: The 'diuers houses' on Bankside at this time included the Rose and the Swan as well as the Globe, now the recently opened base for the lord chamberlain's men. Whether this order had a direct impact on the type of entertainment offered henceforth at the Swan is an open question but Henslowe's Rose continued its operation for at least three more years after the lord admiral's men moved north of the river to the Fortune playhouse. See the Introduction and Foakes, Henslowe's Diary, pp 164, 213â€“26.
The privy councillors present for the issuing of the order are not listed.
For an abstract of the record and details of its transcription in other sources, see the related EMLoT event record.

div.head: f 339 (28 March)
div.ab: ItemItem: in display script it is ordered that the Churchwardens shall talke with the playeres for tithes for theire playhouses & for the Rest of the newe tannehouses neare thereaboutes within the libertie of the Clinke & for monie for the pore accordinge to the order taken before my Lordes of Canterbury, London,my Lordes of Canterbury, London: John Whitgift (c 1530-1604), archbishop of Canterbury, 1583-1604, and Sir William Rider (c 1544-1611), lord mayor of London, 1600 & master of the Revellsmaster of the Revells: Edmund Tilney (c 1536-1610), master of the Revels, 1579-1610./
