div.head: p 179 (15 May) (Greenwich)
div.ab: An open Lettre to the Iustices of peace in the Countie of Surrey, & to all others her Maiestes officers & lovinge Subiectes in that County or Burrough of Southwark to whome yt shall appertain &c. Whereas the Bearer Peter BromvillPeter Bromvill: in italic script hath ben recommended vnto her Maiestie from her good Brother the french kingethe french kinge: Henri IV, and hath shewed som feates of great activity before her highnes; Her Maiestie ys pleased to afforde him her gratious favor, and leave, to exercyse, and shewe the same in soch publicke place as maie be convenient for soche exercyses and shewes; And because for the present he hath made choice of a place called the Swann in old Parys garden, beinge the howse of francis Langley;francis Langley: in italic script These shalbe to let yow vnderstand her Maiestes good pleasure in his behalfe, And to Requir yow not onlie to permytt him there to shewe his feates of activity at convenient tymes in that pleace without let or Interrupcion, but to assyst him (as there shalbe occacon) that no abuse be offered him
Itpostscript of Mr. Secretaryes Hand./ ys not meant that he shall exercyse vpon any Sabothe day.

div.p: Those present at this meeting of the privy council on 15 May are listed in the left margin at the top of the page as follows: Sir Thomas Egerton (1540-1617), lord keeper of the Great Seal, 1596-1617; Thomas Sackville (c 1536-1608), first Baron Buckhurst, lord treasurer,1599-1608; Charles Howard (1536-1624), tenth earl of Nottingham; Roger North (1531-1600), Lord North; Sir William Knollys (c 1545-1632), comptroller of the Household, 1596-1632; and Sir Robert Cecil (1563-1612), secretary of state, 1596-1612.

A letter on 12 May 1600 from Rowland Whyte to Sir Robert Sidney mentions that the queen intended that same day to see a Frenchman (presumably the same Peter Bromvill) do 'feates upon a rope' in the Conduit Court. See Historical Manuscripts Commission, Report on the Manuscripts of Lord De L'Isle & Dudley preserved at Penshurst Place, C.L. Kingsford (ed), vol 2 (London, 1934), 461. Chambers also notes in his Court Calendar that 12 May featured 'activities' by Peter Bromvill (Elizabethan Stage, vol 4, p 112 and n 17). Peter Bromvill had 'danced upon the rope' before the queen. Claire McManus, in 'Women investors and gendered performance at the second Fortune playhouse (2)' for the Shakespeare Association of America meeting (Portland, 2024), notes 'a breathtaking L.333, 6s, 8d. Scots' for Bromville's performance before King James VI and Queen Anna in August 1600 at Falkland Palace (citing The Autobiography and Diary of Mr James Melvill, Robert Pitcairn (ed) (Woodrow Society, 1842), vol 2, 487).
For an abstract of the record and details of its transcription in other sources, see the related EMLoT event record.

div.head: pp 51415 (31 December)
div.ab:
TwoTwo: T in display script Lettres of one tenour to the Iustices of Middlesex & Surrey. It is in vaine for vs to takeLord Keeper Mr Comptrolor
Lord Tresurer Mr Secretary Cecyll
Lord Admirall. Mr Secretary Harberte
Lord Shrewsbury
Lord Worcester. knowledg of greate abuses & disorders complayned of, and to giue order for redresse, if our directions finde no better execution and observation then it seemeth they do: and wee must needes impute the fault and blame thereof to yow or some of yow the Iustices of the peace that are put in trust to see them executed and perfourmed: whereof wee may giue yow a plaine instance in the great abuse contynued or rather encreased in the multitude of Plaie howses and Stage Plaies in and about the Cittie of London. ffor whereas about a yeare & a half since (vpon knowledge taken of the great enormities and disorders by the overmuch frequentinge of Plaies) wee did carefullie sett downe and proscribe an order to be observed concerninge the number of Playhowses, and the vse and exercise of Stage plaies with lymytacion of tymes and places for the same, (namely that there should be but two howses allowed for that vse, one in MiddlesexMiddlesex: in a more formal script called the Fortune,Fortune: in a more formal script and the other in SurreySurrey: in a more formal script called the GlobeGlobe: in a more formal script; and the same with observacion of certaine daies and times as in the said order is particularly expressed) in such sorte as a moderate practice of them for honest recreation might be contynued, and yet the inordinate concourse of dissolute and idle people be restrayned; wee do now vnderstande that our said order hath bin so farr from taking dew effect, as in steede of restrainte and redresse of the former disorders the multitude of play howses is much encreased, and that no daie passeth over without many Stage plaies in one place or other within and about the Cittie publiquelie made; The default of perfourmance of which said our said order, we must in greate parte the rather impute to the Iustices of the peace, because at the same tyme wee gaue earnest direction vnto yow to see it streightly executed; and to certifie vs of the execution; and yet we haue neither vnderstoode of any redresse made by yow nor receaved any Certificate at all of your procedinges therein; which default, or omission, wee do now pray and require yow foorthwith to amende; and to cause our said former order to be putt duely in execution; and especiallie to call before yow the Owners of all the other Play howses (excepting the two howses in Middlesex,Middlesex: in a more formal script and SurreySurrey: in a more formal script aforementioned); and to take good and sufficient bondes of them, not to exercise vse or practice, nor to suffer from henceforth to be exercised, vsed or practized any Stage playinge in their howses, and if they shall refuse to enter into such Bondes, then to Comitt them to prison, vntill they shall conforme themselues. And so &c.

AA: in display scriptSigned & dated as the former./ lettre to the Lord Maiour & Aldermen of London. Wee haue receaued a lettre from yow, renewing a Complaint of the great abuse and disorder within and about the Cittie of London, by reason of the multitude of Play howses, and the inordinate resort and Concourse of dissolute and idle people daielie vnto publique Stage plaies; for the which information, as wee do commende your lordship because it betokeneth your Care and desire to reforme the disorders of the Cittie; So wee must lett yow know, that wee did muche rather expect to vnderstand that our order (sett downe and prescribed about a yeare and a half since for reformation of the said disorders vpon the like Complaint at that tyme) had bin duelie executed, then to finde the same disorders and abuses so muche encreased as they are. The blame whereof, as wee cannot but impute in great part to the Iustices of the peace or some of them in the Counties of Middlesex and Surrey, who had speciall direction and charge from vs to see our said order executed, for the Confines of the Cittie, wherein the most part of those Play howses are scituate; So wee do wishe that it might appeare vnto vs that any thing hath bin endeavoured by the Predecessours of yow the Lord Maiour and by yow the Aldermen for the redresse of the said enormities, and for observation & execution of our said order within the Cittie; wee do therefore once againe renew hereby our directions vnto yow (as we haue donne by our lettres to the Iustices of Middlesex and Surrey) concerninge the observation of our former order: which wee do praie and require yow to cause duelie and dilligentlie to be put in execution for all poyntes thereof, and especiallie for thexpresse & streight prohibition of any more Play howses then those two that are mentioned & allowed in the said
Order:Order: also written as a catchword at the bottom of p 514 Charging & streightlie comaunding all such persons as are the Owners of any the howses vsed for Stage plaies within the Cittie; not to permitt any more publique Plaies to be vsed, exercised, or shewed from hencefoorth in their said howses, And to take bondes of them, (if yow shall finde it needefull) for the perfourmance thereof, Or if they shall refuse to enter into bonde, or to obserue our said order, then to comitt them to Prison vntill they shall conforme themselues thervnto. And so praying yow as yourself do make the Complaint and finde the enormitie; so to applie your best endeauendeau: binding too tight to read to the remedie of the abuse, wee bidd &c.

div.p: The privy councillors present at the meeting on 31 December and listed in the left marginalia are as follows: Sir Thomas Egerton (1540-1617), lord keeper of the Great Seal, 1596-1617; Sir William Knollys (c 1545-1632), comptroller of the Household, 1596-1632; Thomas Sackville (1536-1608), Lord Buckhurst and lord treasurer, 1599-1608; Sir Robert Cecil(1563-1612), principal secretary, 1596-1612; Charles Howard (1536-1624), tenth earl of Nottingham and lord admiral, 1585-1619; Sir John Herbert (1540-1617), second secretary, 1600-17; Gilbert Talbot (1552-1616), tenth earl of Shrewsbury; and Edward Somerset (c 1550-1628), ninth earl of Worcester.

The signatories included not only the privy councillors listed in the left marginalia but also John Whitgift (1530/1?-1604), archbishop of Canterbury, 1583-1604; Sir John Popham, lord chief justice of the Queen's Bench, 1592-1607; and Sir John Stanhope, vice-chamberlain, before 1600/1-1616, and treasurer of the chamber, before 1597-1617/18. The full text of the Remembrancia letter is printed in Greg and Chambers, 'Remembrancia,' pp 83-5.
For an abstract of the record and details of its transcription in other sources, see the related EMLoT event record.

div.head: single sheet (6 November)
div.ab: FIRST,FIRST: F centred in a decorative woodblock there is induct by shew and in Action, the ciuill warres of England from Edward the third, to the end of Queene Maries raigne, with the ouerthrow of Vsurpation.

2 Secondly then the entrance of Englands Ioy by the Coronation of our Soueraigne Lady Elizabeth; her Throne attended with peace, Plenty, and ciuill Pollicy: A sacred Prelate standing at her right hand, betokening the Serenity of the Gospell: At her left hand Iustice: And at her feete Warre, with a Scarlet Roabe of peace vpon his Armour: A wreath of Bayes about his temples, and a braunch of Palme in his hand.
3 Thirdly is dragd in three Furies, presenting Dissention, Famine, and Bloudshed, which are throwne downe into hell.

4 Fourthly is exprest vnder the person of a Tyrant, the enuy of Spayne, who to shew his cruelty causeth his Souldiers dragge in a beautifull Lady, whome they mangle and wound, tearing her garments and Iewels from off her: And so leaue her bloudy, with her hayre about her shoulders, lying vpon the ground. To her come certaine Gentlemen, who seeing her pitious dispoylment, turne to the Throne of England, from whence one descendeth, taketh vp the Lady, wipeth her eyes, bindeth vp her woundes, giueth her treasure, and bringeth forth a band of Souldiers, who attend her forth: This Lady presenteth Belgia.

5 Fiftly, the Tyrant more enraged, taketh counsell, sends forth letters, priuie Spies, and secret vnderminers, taking their othes, and giuing them bagges of treasure. These signifie Lopus,Lopus: Dr Roderigo Lopez, Jewish-Portuguese physician to the queen, incriminated in a Spanish plot against her life and executed, 1594 and certaine Iesuites, who afterward, when the Tyrant lookes for an answere from them, are shewed to him in a glasse with halters about their neckes, which makes him mad with fury.
6 Sixtly, the Tyrant seeing all secret meanes to fayle him, intendeth open violence and inuasion by the hand of Warre, whereupon is set forth the battle at Sea in 88. with Englands victory.

7 Seuenthly, hee complotteth with the Irish rebelles, wherein is layd open the base ingratitude of Tyrone,Tyrone: ie, the rebellion led by Hugh O'Neill 1585-1595, third earl of Tyrone, 1603-1607 the landing there of Don Iohn de Aguila,Don Iohn de Aguila: Spanish general and leader of invading forces and their dissipation by the wisedome and valour of the Lord MountioyLord Mountjoy: Charles, Blount, eighth Baron Mountjoy.
8 Eightly, a great triumph is made with fighting of twelue Gentlemen at Barriers, and sundrie rewards sent from the Throne of England, to all sortes of well deseruers.

9 Lastly, the Nine Worthyes, with seuerall Coronets, present themselues before the Throne, which are put backe by certaine in the habite of Angels, who set vpon the Ladies head, which represents her Maiestie, an Emperiall Crowne, garnished with the Sunne, Moone and Starres; And so with Musicke both with voyce and Instruments shee is taken vp into Heauen, when presently appeares, a Throne of blessed Soules, and beneath vnder the Stage set forth with strange fireworkes, diuers blacke and damned Soules, wonderfully discribed in their seuerall torments.

div.p:
John Chamberlain's amusing account of events at the Swan in a letter to Dudley Carleton on 19 November (TNA: SP12/285) reveals that Vennar was unable to pull off this ambitious one-day production â€“ and indeed probably never intended to, despite the broadside promotion of its plot. However, the play was finally staged in 1615 at another theatre, with William Fennor among the actors. John Taylor, A Cast over the Water (1615), sig B5v, includes Fennor's poorly received performance in a mocking reference to the play: 'Indeed, thou set'st the people in a rage
In playing Englands Ioy, that euery Man
Did iudge it worse then that was done at Swan.
I neuer saw poore fellow so behist,
T'applaud thee, few or none lent halfe a fist...' Taylor (sig C3) goes on to mention Fennor's swindling of 'poore old Vennor, that plaine dealing man,
Who acted Englands Ioy first at the Swan,' perhaps a tongue in cheek salute to Vennor's own dubious 'plain dealing.'

There is also an undated poem by 'R.V.' (Richard Vennar) called Englands Ioy (STC: 24636.3), celebrating the same victory against the Irish rebels led by Tyrone and their Spanish allies under Don Juan de Aguila. Baron Mountjoy's victory at Kensale took place on 24 December 1601, so the poem may have been published around the same time that Vennar announced his play.

div.head: f [1v] (11 February)
div.ab: On monday last here was a great prise and challenge performed at the swan betwene two fencers DunDun: John Dun and turnerturner: John Turner, a well-known fencing master, wherin Dun had so yll lucke that the other ran him into the eye with foyle, and so far into the head that he fell downe starke dead and neuer spoke word nor once moued. the case is, and wilbe much argued by lawiers whether yt will proue chaunce medley, manslaughter or murder, by reason of malice and many challenges past betweene them before.

div.p:
Some years later Joseph Swetnam, The Schoole of the Noble and Worthy Science of Defence (2nd ed, 1617), STC: 23543, sigs C3vâ€“C4, recalled this incident: 'And now (for examples sake) I thinke it not amisse to renew your remembrance with the death of some few of the Noble Science, because I haue knowne their ends; and first, to beginne with that one of maister Turner, which should be the last, he did not so speedily kill Iohn Dun, with a thrust in the eie, but he was as soone murthered afterwards, with a shotte of a Pistoll; for neither of them, after they had their deaths wound, spake one word; loe by this you may see, that some hawkes are but a flight, and horses are killed with a tournie, and a man is but a shotte; but now, by reason that Maister Turner, by his vnluckie hand, thrust out two or three eies, and because none others are knowne to doe the like, it hath therefore bred an admiration in the ignorant and vulgare sort, insomuch, that generally they doe applaude him with this commendation, saying that hee hath not left the like behinde him, nor neuer will be the like againe: But this is a great errour in thinking so, and farre deceiued are they; for I well know Maister Turner by familair acquaintance, and therefore (to speake the right) he was a worthy fellow and deserued well, but yet I know many which can goe neare the eie as euer he could doe, if they so listed, as in this booke you shall see many false thrusts at seuerall weapons which may
endanger any mans eies, if those which learne them doe carry enuious mindes, or if they were desirous to worke a man such a mischiefe, but God forbid that any man should be so ill minded, I will not say, but that by chaunce such a thing may be done, and so it may bee that Maister Turner did it more by chance, without any intention'

Jay P. Anglin, 'The Schools of Defense in Elizabethan London,' Renaissance Quarterly 37.3 (1984), 406, notes that John Turner was shot dead on 11 May 1612 by Robert Carlysle, one of two assassins hired by Robert Crichton, eighth Lord Crichton of Sanquhar (c 1568â€“1612). Crichton had lost an eye in a fencing match with Turner in 1604 but did not seek revenge until 1612. He and both assassins were subsequently hanged (see M.J. Bowman, 'Crichton, Robert, eighth Lord Crichton of Sanquhar (c 1568â€“1612), nobleman and murderer,' ODNB, accessed 27 October 2024).
For an abstract of the record and details of its transcription in other sources, see the related EMLoT event record.

div.head: f 366v (c May)
div.ab: That all playes Bearebaytinges games singing of balletts buckler play or such like causes of assemblies be vtterlie prohibited and the parties offending severely punished by any Alderman or Iustice of the peace./

div.head: ff 67â€“8 (8 November)
div.ab:
After ourAfter our: in display script with decorated initial Affrom the Lordes, for the suppressinge of Stage plaies, Bearebaytinges, and idle shewes, vpon the death of Prince Henry/. very hartie h Commendacions to your Lordshipp/2 Whereas it hath pleased the Almightie God, to take awaie the most Noble and worthie Prince of Wales, to the exceedinge greate sorrowe and Greef aswell of theire Maiesties, as of all theire deere and lovinge Subiecte/. And
that thesethat these: also written at foot of previous folio as catchwords tymes doe not suite with such playes and idle shewes, as are daily to be seene in and neere the cittie of London, to the scandall of Order and good governement at all occasions when they are most tolerable, As wee haue allreadie addressed lettres to the Iustices of peace of Middlesex and Surrey for the suppressinge of any playes or shewes whatsoever within those Counties, soe wee doe heereby require your Lordshipp to take speedie and speciall order for the prohibitinge of all Playes shewes Bearebaytinges, or any other such sighte, within that cittie and liberties thereof and vtterlie to restraine, the vse and exercise thereof vntill you shall receave further order from vs/. And yf you shall finde anie person offendinge therein, to commytt him or them to Prison without favour or connyvauncie, and to acquainte vs therewith/. And soe wee bidd your lordship / Hartelie farewell/. ffrom Whitehall the viijth of November /./ 1612/.

T Ellesmore CancellariusT Ellesmore Cancellarius: Thomas Egerton (1540-1617), first Viscount Brackley, appointed lord chancellor, 1603 H Northampton: H Northampton: Henry Howard (1540â€“1614), ninth earl of Northampton T Suffolk: T Suffolk: Thomas Howard (1561â€“1626), eleventh earl of Suffolk
E Wotton E Wotton: Edward Wotton (1548â€“1628), first Baron Wotton, Stanhop/Stanhop: John Stanhope (c1540â€“1621), first Baron Stanhope of Harrington.

div.head: p 16
div.ab: For who can excuse my publique default of the Swan, where not a Collier but cals his deere 12. pence to witnesse the disaster of the day? How should I, without blushing, deny the name of England's Ioy, who had so many Gossips at my Christening? Surely, this diuill must be cast out at leasure; you must vse some patience to heare, and I rob you of a little more time to deliuer the circumstance, which with indifferency heard, I assure my selfe will proue but a Chimera, and either appeare but a winde, or Ixions monster, at most, part man, part beast.

div.head: pp 22â€“7
div.ab:
I saw a
daily offring to the God of pleasure, resident at the Globe on the Banke-side, of much more then would have supplyed my then want; I noted euery mans hand ready to feed the luxury of his eye, that puld downe his hat to stop the sight of his charity, wherefore I concluded to make a friend of Mammon, and to giue them sound for words, both being but aire, for which they should giue double payment, to the intent onely, men of ability might make the purchase without repentance, and my selfe obserue that wise rule of Phylosophy; Non fiat per plura quod potest fieri per pauciora:Non â€¦ pauciora: 'Let it not be done with many things what can be done with fewer.' My deuise was all sorts of
Musique, beginning with Chambers, the Harpe of war, and ending with Hounds,
the cry of peace, of which I was doubly prouided, for Fox and Hare.

The report of Gentlemen and Gentlewomens actions, being indeed the flagge to our Theater, was not meerely falcification, for I had diuers Chorus to bee spoken by men of good birth, Schollers by profession; protesting that the businesse was meerely abused, by the comming of some Beagles vpon mee, that were none of the intended Kennell, I meane Baylifes, who seizing mee before the first entrance, spoke an Epilogue instead of a Prologue, this changed the play into the hunting of the Fox; which, that the world may know for a verity, I heere promise the next Tearme, with the true history of my
life, to bee publiquely presented, to insert in place of Musicke, for the actes, all those intendments prepared for that daies entertainement: Which, seeing it must rest in your beliefes till then, I will bee content so long to weare your Apellation, preferring onely in this Imputation, so farre the part of an Apologist, that drawing the accident it selfe, without defence, into iudicious question, this Scoggins Crow, that hath filled so many mouths will proue but a Rooke. For suppose that the play was hist, was I the first Poet made my Clients penitents, let the burning pestle bee heard in my cause, which rang so dismally in your eares, and yet the Writer in state of Grace.

The difference was, I presented you with a Dumbe Show, and the Players say, that is alwaies as good as a bad act, neither could the cost bee great, that for one twelue pence, afforded mirth for a Twelue-month after: At the highest rate, you lent mee but an after-noones hearing, the expectation being worth the money: since Phylosophers say, that the sweetnesse of hope is beyond the enjoying, and in this sense, I bettered that daies trauell, the errour being your owne, that being ignorant of a Logitian, stile mee an Impostor, from which I am so farre, that the Law shall speake for mee, whch presupposeth euery man good, till hee bee conuicted bad; And I presume it came not within the
compasse of an inditement: The conclusion is this, I had too many Patrons for so slender a worke, and for that fault, this Apologie is my sufficient answere. Neither is it strange to haue so much mony for six verses, since Bonum quo communius eo melius.Bonum â€¦ melius: 'the more common a good thing is the better' And Poetry in a more legitimate age, hath beene held cosin-germane to goodnesse, but were there no more holes in this vessell, you might soone stop the leake.

div.head: sig B6v (My Defence against thy Offence)
div.ab: Thou brag'st what fame thou got'st vpon the stage
Indeed, thou set'st the people in a rage
In playing Englands Ioy, that euery Man
Did iudge it worse then that was done at Swan.
I neuer saw poore fellow so behist,
T'applaud thee, few or none lent halfe a fist:
Some stinkards hands, perhaps went pit to pat,
Who ignorantlie lik'd they knew not what;
Besides thou know'st, thou promist in thy Bill,
In rare Extemporie to shew thy skill.
When all thou spok'st, thou studied'st had before,
Thou know'st I know, aboue a month and more.
Besides, the best conceits that were in it
(Poore Foole) thou had'st them from a better wit
Then is thine owne, thy beggerly conceit
Could neere haue mounted to so high a height.
Good wine is spild, in stinking vessels leaking,
And so good words were mar'd with thy ill speaking:
Where (like a Scar-crow) or a Iack of lent
Thou stood'st, and gau'st the people smal content:
And yet thy impudence would'st raise thy fame,
From out the loathsome Garbage of thy shame.
Thy little honestie so high thou deem'st,
And more then Thames reuennew it esteem'st:

div.head: p 509 (26 September)
div.ab: It is ordered that Mr. LeakeMr. Leake: Henry Leake shall paye for his mansion house of the mannor of Parris garden and for his garden & orchard & for the house wherein BaxterBaxter: Robert Baxter ? dwelt with the litle platt of ground in which Baxters house standeth xx s. tithe per annum, the playhouse being excepted/

div.p: Henry Leake (d. 1622) was a parishioner of St Saviour's parish who moved into the manor house by 1612. See further, the Introduction.
A Robert Baxter is named as living 'near the playhouse' in Paris Garden manor in the Token Books, 1614-15.

div.head: sig [A1]
div.ab: A
CHAST MAYD
IN
CHEAPE-SIDE.
A
Pleasant conceited Comedy
neuer before printed.
As it hath beene often acted at the
Swan on the Banke-side, by the
Lady ELIZABETH her
Seruants.
By THOMAS MIDDLETON Gentleman

div.head: sig F2v
div.ab: and aboue all the rest, she was most taken with the report of three famous Amphytheators, which stood so neere scituated, that her eye might take view of them from her lowest Turret, one was the Continent of the World, because halfe the yeere a World of Beauties, and braue Spirits resorted vnto it; the other was a building of excellent Hope, and though wild beasts and Gladiators, did most possesse it, yet the Gallants that came to behold those combats, though they were of a mixt Society, yet were many Noble worthies amongst them; the last which stood, and as it were shak'd handes with this Fortresse, beeing in times past, as famous as any of the other, was now fallen to decay, and like a dying Swanne, hanging downe her head, seemed to sing her owne dierge;

div.p: Dona Hollandia finds the ideal location for her brothel 'out of the Citie, yet in the view of the Citie, only divided by a delicate River' (sig F1), with a tradition of 'open Hospitality' and nearby playhouses that would help to draw customers â€“ the Globe or 'Continent of the World'; the Hope, home to gladiators and wild beasts, and the Swan, now fallen into decay.
For an abstract of the record and details of its transcription in other sources, see the related EMLoT event record.

div.head: f [1v] (19 November)
div.ab: and now we are in mirth I must not forget to tell you of a cousening prancke of one venner of Lincolns ynne that gaue out bills of a famous play on satterday was seuenight on the banckside to be acted only by certain gentlemen and gentlewomen of account, the price at comming in was two shillings or eighteen pence at least and when he had gotten most part of the mony into his hands, he wold haue shewed them a fayre payre of heeles, but he was not so nimble to get vp on horsebacke, but that he was faine to forsake that course, and betake himself to the water, where he was pursued and taken and brought before the Lord Cheife Iustice, who wold make nothing of yt but a iest and merriment, and bound him ouer in fiue pound to appeare at the sessions: in the meane time the common people when they saw themselues deluded, reuenged themselues vpon the hangings curtaines chaires stooles walles and whatsoeuer came in theyre way very outragiously and made a great spoyle: there was great store of goode companie and many noblemen

div.p: Richard Vennar (1564â€“1615) was admitted to Lincoln's Inn on 10 June 1581 and resided there for much of his turbulent career. See further Berry, 'Richard Vennar, England's Joy,' pp 240â€“65; Chambers, Elizabethan Stage, vol 3, pp 500â€“3; and Vennar's own account of the much-mocked and abortive performance at the Swan in An Apology, published in 1614 and transcribed in this edition.

In his broadside, The Plot of the Play Called 'England's Joy' (1602), Vennar announced its performance at the Swan on 6 November 1602. According to Vennar's account years later in 1614, he was only able to deliver six lines of the prologue on stage, before bailiffs appeared to arrest him for debt. Although he pocketed 'much mony,' the authorities did not indict him (Vennar, Apology, p 27). The play was finally mounted by William Fennor in the spring of 1615, another performance mocked by John Taylor in A Cast Over Water (1615).
For an abstract of the record and details of its transcription in other sources, see the related EMLoT event record.

div.head: f 98 (7 February)
div.ab: Turner7: and Dun two famous fencers playd their prizes this day at the banke side: but Turner at last ran Dun soe far in the brayne at the eye, that he fell downe presently stone deade/./ a goodly sport in a Chrstian state, to see on man kill an other in

div.p: The venue on Bankside is known to have been the Swan Playhouse in Paris Garden from John Chamberlain's letter to Dudley Carleton on 11 February (TNA: SP12/287). John Turner and John Dun were famous master fencers of the period.

On 24 May 1589, Francis Langley acquired by deed the lordship and manor of Paris Garden, paying Â£850 for the property. Thomas Cure the Younger would convey the property and manor house before the feast of the Nativity of St John the Baptist that same year. See further the Introduction: History of the Property.

On 1 December 1601 Hugh and his son Thomas Browker assumed the lease of the manor of Paris Garden from Francis and Jane Langley. For a more detailed account of the desperate financial circumstances and context for Langley's sale of the lease, see further Ingram, London Life, pp 250â€“67. Ingram, p 322, notes that the final step in the transfer of ownership from Langley to Browker concluded on 3 February 1602 (Feet of Fines, CP 25(2)/228/44ELIZIHIL, mb 4; see also Ingram, p 322 n 26). My special thanks to Patrick Gregory, REED Associate Editor and Latinist, for his transcription and translation of this lease.

This undated document from the seventeenth century is titled â€˜Lands Concealed and to be obteyned of the Kings Ma{ies}tie.â€™ The lands had formerly belonged to the Knights Templar, but on suppression of the order, the manor was granted to the Knights Hospitaller. In 1536 it was surrendered to the Crown. The date c March 1606 has been assigned by a much later handwritten note and has been accepted by some others (for example, Herbert Berry, 'The Swan,' (Berry et al, English Professional Theatre, pp 439, 448). However, the St Saviour's Token Books list an Alexander Welch living near the playhouse for only three years, between 1627â€“9, so the early dating to 1606 should be questioned. See Ingram and Nelson, Token Books, the 1627 entry for Alexander Welch. Further, it is known that others were living in the manor house in the period when the Swan was occasionally used following the death of Francis Langley. Alexander Walsh (Welch) would therefore seem an unlikely candidate for management of the playhouse in the early seventeenth century. See further the Introduction: History of the Property.

div.head: mbs [1]â€“3 (24 May)
div.ab:
ThisIndentura inter Cure et langley Indenture made the foure and twentith daye of Maye in the one and thirtith yere of the raigne of our soueraigne ladye Elizabeth by the gifte of god Quene of England ffraunce and Irelande defendor of
the faith &c Betwene Thomas Cure of Southwarke in the Countie of Surrey Esquier on thone partie and ffrauncis langley Citezen and Draper of london on thother partie Witnesseth that the saide Thomas Cure for the consideracion hereunder mencioned doth for hym his heyres and executors covenaunte graunte and agree to and with the saide ffrauncis langley his heyres and assignes and everie of them by theise presentes That he the saide Thomas Cure or his heyres shall and will before the ffeaste of the Natyvytie of St Iohn Baptiste next commyng after the date hereof att and vppon the reasonable request or requestes of the saide ffrauncis langley his heyres and assignes and att the costes and chardges in the lawe of the same Thomas Cure his heyres and assignes lawfullye and presentlye convey and assure or cause to be conveyed and assured vnto the saide ffrauncis langley his heyres and assignes or vnto suche other parson or parsons and theire heyres to theire sole and onlye vse and vses forever as the saide ffraunces langley his heyres or assignes shall name and appoynte a good sure sufficient lawfull perfecte and indeficible estate in the lawe in fee symple absolute without condicion or lymytacion of other vses of and in all that the lordeshippe and mannor of Parys Gardeyne in the Countie of Surrey with his rightes royalties members and appurtenaunces whatsoever and of and in all that mancion or mancion howse of the saide lordshippe and mannor of Paris Gardeyne aforesaide with thappurtenaunces in the same Countie scituate and being within the moate there and of and in all those two gardens there abutting vppon the saide mansion howse and of and in all that howse called the gatehowse there and of and in all those foure pastures called the ponde yarde the Connygree the Chappell haule and Walnuttes and of and in all those two other pastures aboute the Banckes there called the Willowes with theire appurtenaunces whatsoever and of and in all and singuler mesuages howses edyffices barnes stables gardens orchardes landes tenementes meadowes leasnes pastures waters fysshinges rentes reuercions seruices Courtes leetes veiwe of francke pledge profittes and perquisittes of Courtes and leetes and all that which Courtes leetes and veiwe of franckpledge apperteyneth wayves and stayes goodes and chattelles of felons and fugitives deodandes and all other iurisdiccions franchises priuiledges profittes commodities and heredytamentes whatsover lying and being or renewing in the towne parishe hamlettes and feildes of St Saviors in the saide Countie of Surrey Parys Gardeyne aforesaide or ellswhere in the saide Countie to the saide lordshippe and mannor and other the premysses belonging or apperteyning or accepted vsed knowne or reputed as parte parcell or member thereof And all and all manner Woodes vnderwoodes and trees in and vppon the premysses growing and being And the reuercion and reuercions of all and singuler the same premisses and euerye parte and parcell thereof which were by the right honorable Sir Henry Carye knight lorde Hunsdon and lord Chamberleyn of her maiesties howsehold Robert Newdigate Esquier and Arthure ffountayne gentleman amongest others latelye assured vnto the saide Thomas Cure and his heyres forever by the name of Thomas Cure the yonger And that in suche manner and forme as by the saide ffrauncis langley his heyres or assignes or his or theire learned Councell in the lawe shalbe reasonablie devysed or advysed and alsoe the saide Thomas Cure for the consideracion aforesaide doth covenaunt graunte and agree for hym his heyres and executors to and with the saide ffrauncis langley his heyres and assignes by theise presentes That the saide lordshippe and mannor mansion howse landes tenementes pastures and all and singular other the premysses with thappurtenaunces and euerye parte and parcell thereof afore mencioned to be conveyed and assured nowe are and be and att the tyme of thexecucion of the same estate shalbe and soe from thensforth shall contynue and endure vnto the saide ffrauncis langley his heyres and assignes free and clerely acquited exonerated and dischardged or otherwyse shalbe from tyme to tyme vppon requeste had sufficientlye saved and kepte harmeles by the saide Thomas Cure his heyres and assignes of and from all and euerye former bargaynes sales gyftes grauntes leases rentes statutes bondes recognizaunces iudgementes execucions intrusions and of and from all other chardges titles troubles and encombraunces whatsoever The rentes and seruices fromhenceforth to be due to theyse lorde or lordes of the fee or fees thereof and one lease heretofore made of the premysees which shall expyre and determyn in the ffeast of St Michaell Tharchaungell which shalbe in the yere of our lord god one thowsande fyve hundreth fowerscore and fyftene whereupon the yerelye rente of tenne poundes of lawfull money of England is reserved and fromhenceforth shalbe comme due and payable vnto the saide ffrauncis langley and his heyres for the same during the contynuanunce of the same lease onlye excepte and further the saide Thomas Cure for the consideracion aforesaide dothe for hym his heyres and executors covenaunte graunte and agree to and with the saide ffrauncis langley his heyres and assignes by theise presentes That the saide Thomas Cure att thensealinge and delyuerye of theise presentes is and att the tyme of thexecucion of thestate afore lymytted shalbe seazed of a good and lawfull perfecte and indeficible estate in the lawe in fee symple to hym his heyres and assignes forever absolute without anye manner of condicion entayle or mortgage by good and rightfull title and shall then have in hym selfe full and absolute power and aucthoritie to gyve graunte bargayne sell and assure the saide lordshipp or mannor landes tenementes and heredytamentes and all and singuler other the premysses afore mencioned to be assured and euerye parte and parcell thereof vnto the saide ffrauncis langley his heyres and assignes to his and theire owne proper vse and vses forever in manner and forme aforesaide and that the saide ffrauncis langley his heyres and assignes shall or maye lawfullie have holde possesse inheritt and enioye the saide lordshipp or mannor landes tenementes heredytamentes and all and singuler other the premisses afore mencioned to be assured and euerye parte and parcell thereof from henceforth forever without anye manner of lawfull lett trouble denyall interupcion or other ympedymente of the saide Thomas Cure his heyres or assignes or of anye other parson or parsons whatsoever other then is before mencioned and excepted and whereas the saide Thomas Cure ioyntlye with George Cure Esquier his brother heretofore did knowledge vnto George Payne of Southwark aforesaide Grocer one recognizaunce for the performaunce of dyuerse covenauntes grauntes and articles conteyned in a payre of Indentures made betwene the saide George Cure and George Payne The saide Thomas Cure dothe lykewyse for hym his heyres and executors covenaunte graunte and agree to and with the saide ffrauncis langley his heyres and executors by theise presentes That he the saide Thomas Cure his heyres and executors shall and will on thisside and before the saide ffeaste of the Natiuitie of St Iohn Baptiste next commyng procure and cause the saide George Payne his heyres and executors to covenaunte and graunte by wryting vnder his hande and seale to and with the saide ffrauncis langley his heyres and executors That he his heyres executors or assignes or anye of them or anye others by anye wayes or meanes shall not att anye tyme or tymes hereafter procure or take anye advauntage or execucion vppon the saide lordshippe or mannor and other the premysses hereby mencioned to be assured by force vertue or meanes of the saide recognizaunce in suche manner and forme as by the saide ffrauncis langley his heyres or assignes or his or theire learned Councell in the lawe shalbe reasonablye devysed or advysed In consideracion of which the saide seuerall covenauntes grauntes and agreementes to be performed observed done and accomplished in manner and forme aforesaide The saide ffrauncis langley for hym his heyres and exceutors covenaunteth promysseth and graunteth to and with the saide Thomas Cure his heyres and executors by theise presentes That he the saide ffrauncis langley his heyres executors or assignes shall and will well and trulye contente and paye or cause to be contented and payde vnto the saide Thomas Cure and his heyres or
assignes the somme of eight hundreth and fyftie poundes of lawfull money of England in manner and forme following that is to saye att thensealing and delyuerye hereof fyftie and fyve poundes parcell thereof whereof and wherewith the saide Thomas Cure knowledgeth hym selfe well and trulye contented and payde and of the saide fyftie and fyve poundes dothe clerelye acquite and dyschardge the saide ffrauncis langley his heyres and executors by theise presentes and on or before the saide ffeast of the Natiuitie of St Iohn Baptist next commyng vnto Robert Peter Esquier his executors or assignes by thassignement of the saide Thomas Cure fyve hundreth and fyftie poundes other parcell thereof for and in dyschardge of two seuerall wrytinges obligatories latelye made and prouided by estatute for the recoverie and payment of debtes wherein the saide Thomas Cure standeth bounde vnto the saide Robert Peter in the somme of one thowsand poundes of lawfull money of England and vnto Iohn Savage Citizen and Sadler of london his executors or assignes by thassignement of the saide Thomas Cure the somme of one hundreth poundes parcell thereof in discharge of two leases made by the saide Thomas Cure vnto the saide Iohn Savage of the saide lordshippe or mannor and other the premisses on or before the saide ffeast of the Natiuitie of St Iohn Baptiste next commyng and vnto Wiilliam Danbye gentleman his executors or assignes by thassignemente of the saide Thomas Cure the somme of fyftie poundes on other parcell thereof lykewyse before the saide ffeaste in discharge of a lease lykewise made by the saide Thomas Cure vnto the saide William Danbye of the saide lordshippe or mannor and other the premisses and vnto the saide Thomas Cure his executors or assignes within fourtene dayes next after that the same Thomas Cure shall have soe sufficientlye assured and conveyed the saide lordshippe or mannor and other the premisses vnto the saide ffrauncis langley his heyres and assignes or vnto suche other parson and parsons and theire heyres to theire owne vse and vses forever as the saide ffrauncis or his heyres shall name and appoynte as by â€¸the good advyse of master William ffleetewood Esquier seriante att lawe and recorder of the Cittie of london or master Thomas Owen of lincolns Inne in the Countie of Middlesex Esquier shalbe lymytted and appoynted fowerscore and fyftene poundes residue and in full satisfacion and payment of the saide eight hundreth and fyftie poundes without fraude or covyn/ In witnes whereof the parties aforesaide to theise present Indentures enterchaungeablye have sett theire handes and seales yeoven the daye and yeare fyrst above written

Et memorandum quod decimo octauo Nouembris anno regni dicte domine nostre Elizabeth Regine tricesimo secundoannoâ€¦tricesimo secundo: 1590 prefatus Thomas Cure armiger venit coram dicta domina Regina in Cancellaria sua et recognouit Indenturam predictam ac omnia et singula in eadem contenta et spicificata in forma supradictaEtâ€¦supradicta: written in display script; 'And be it recorded that on 10 November in thirty-second year of the reign of our said lady, Queen Elizabeth, the aforesaid Thomas Cure, esquire, came before the said lady queen in her chancery and acknowledged the aforesaid indenture and all and each of the the things contained and specified in the same in the form abovesaid.'.

div.head: mb 40 (1 December)
div.ab: Regina.licencia alienandi inter langley & Browker Omnibus ad quos &c Salutem. Sciatis quod nos de gratia nostra speciali ac pro quadraginta sex solidis & octo denarijs solutis ffirmario nostro virtute harum nostrarum patentium concessimus & licenciam dedimus ac pro nobis heredibus & successoribus nostris quantum in nobis est per presentes concedimus & licenciam damus Dilectis nobis ffrancisco langley & Iane vxori eius quod ipsi manerium de Parrys garden cum pertinentijs ac quatuor mesuagijs duo Tofta quatuor gardinis decem acrisque quiquaginta acris prati triginta acris pasture vna acra bosci cum pertinentijs in parochia Sancti Saluatoris in Sowthwarke in Comitatu nostro Surrie Que de nobis tenentur in Capite vt dicitur dare possint & concedere alienare aut cognoscere per finem vel per Extractum recuperacionem in Curia nostra coram Iusticarijs nostris de Banco aut aliquo alio modo quocunque ad libitum ffrancisci & Iane Dilectis nobis hugoni Browker Armigero & Thome Browker generoso habenda & tenenda eisdem hugoni & Thome ac heredibus & assignatis suis ad opus & vsum ipsorum hugonis & Thome ac heredum & assignatorum suorum imperpetuum de nobis heredibus & successoribus nostris per seruicia inde debita & de iure consuetudinis Et eisdem hugoni & Thome quod ipsi predicta manerium mesuagia terras tenenementa & cetera premissa cum pertintijs a prefatis ffrancisco & Iana recipere possint & tenere sibi ac heredibus & assignis suis de nobis heredibus & successoribus nostris per seruicia predicta sicut predictum est imperpetuum tenore presencium similiter licenciam dedimus ac pro nobis heredibus & sucessoribus nostris predictis damus specialem Nolentes quod predicti ffranciscus & Iana vel heredes sui aut prefati hugo & Thomas vel heredes sui racione premissorum per nos heredes vel successores nostros aut per Iusticarios Escaetores vicecomites Balliuos aut alios Officarios seu ministros nostros aut dictorum heredum vel successorum nostrorum quoscunque inde Occasionentur molestentur impetantur vexentur in aliquo seu grauentur nec eorum aliquis occasionetur molestetur Impetatur vexetur in aliquo seu grauetur In cuius rei &c. T R apud Westmonastarium primo die Decembris

div.head: mb 40 (1 December)
div.ab: TheLicense to alienate between Langley and Browker queen to all to whom, etc., greetings. Know that we from our special grace and for 46s 8d paid to our lessee (or farmer) by virtue of these our (letters) patent, have granted and given license, and for us, our heirs and successors, as much as is in us, by the presents do grant and give license to our beloved Francis Langley and Jane, his wife, that they be able to give and grant, alienate or acknowledge by fine or byEstreat recovery in our court before our justices of the bench or by any other manner whatsoever it pleases Francis and Jane, to our beloved Hugh Browker, esquire, and Thomas Browker, gentleman, the manor of Paris Garden with appurtenances and four messuages, two tofts, four gardens and ten acres, fifty acres of meadow, thirty acres of pasture, one acre of woodland, with appurtenances in the parish of St Saviour's in Southwark in our county of Surrey, which is held of us in capite as it is said, to have and to hold, to the same Hugh and Thomas and their heirs and assigns for the benefit and use of the same Hugh and Thomas and of their heirs and assigns in perpetuity from us, our heirs and successors by service owed thereto and from the right of custom. And to the same Hugh and Thomas we have likewise given by the tenor of these presents, and, for us and our heirs and successors aforesaid, do give special licence that they be able to receive and hold for themselves and their heirs and assigns the aforesaid manor, messuages, lands, tenements and the rest of the premises with appurtenances from the aforesaid Francis and Jane, from us, our heirs and successors, by the aforesaid service just as was aforesaid in perpetuity, not wishing that the aforesaid Francis and Jane or their heirs or the aforesaid Hugh and Thomas or their heirs, by reason of the premises, be on that account troubled, molested, abused, vexed in anything or burdened, nor that anyone of them be troubled, molested, abused, vexed in anything or burdened by us, our heirs or successors or by our justices, escheators, sheriffs, bailiffs or other officers or ministers or any of those of our said heirs or successors. In (witness) of which matter, etc, T.R. at Westminster, 1 December.

div.head: f [1]
div.ab: Those that dwell there in the holy ghost lane and at the ould parishe gardenstayers are parishioners to the Templethe Temple: ie, the 12th-c. church of the Knights Templar across the river and had there a Chappell of ease to the Temple wheruppon is nowe built the signe of the swanne and is in the occupacion of one Alexander walshe a ffruiterer.
There are also twoe houses or tenements built vpon some part of the Chappellyarde in the occupacion of (blank) and thother part therof is imployed to the drying of Clothes.
Divers of the inhabitants there haue of late offered Contribucion toward ether reedifieing of the same Chappell
There is a greate quantitie of ground parcell of the same which is called Copt hall in the occupacion of (blank)
There is a mannor house parcell therof wherin the said Walshe dwelleth and by his steward houldeth Court once or more in the yeare./

div.p: For an abstract of the record and details of its transcription in other sources, see the related EMLoT event record.

div.head: Inventory of Plays Possibly Performed at the Swan Playhouse

div.p: This inventory of plays mostly consists of those only possibly associated with the Swan Playhouse. Wiggins and Richardson' annotated catalogue British Drama 1533â€“1642, vols 2â€“4, serves as authority for the title, authors, troupes, genre and status listed below. Further details of date, plot, roles, staging, sources, performance history, and more for each play are provided â€“â€“ as far as possible â€“â€“ in that source, according to a numbering system provided here, by volume. See also Wiggins' 'Introduction,' vol 1, for the scope and limitations, content, format and arrangement of the catalogue.!

The number of lost plays listed below reveals how difficult it is to assess any individual company preferences for tragedies and histories over, for example, comedies, in their repertory. The ongoing collaborative work of contributors to the Lost Plays Database (https://lostplays.folger.edu) is a further valuable contribution to repertory studies.

row.cell: Ben Jonson, George Chapman and John Marston
